Player turns consist of three phases: Terraforming, Recruiting, and Deployment. Terraforming expands the play area by adding new mineable Tiles to the board. Recruiting new Stations is done by rolling and re-rolling Station Dice; each Tile can only be mined by specific Station Dice combinations, for example: sets, straights, larges, odds, etc. The Deployment phase is when you place your Dice on the board. As Stations are deployed, they attack and possibly destroy enemies in neighboring sectors. Each Tile grants an advantage for either mining or deploying Dice to them. And no turn is ever wasted, with single use Utility Cards that are provided to players who are either unable or unwilling to make a deployment.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid

name: Plastic Hell
description:
Who hasn’t been to the toy store or the dollar store and seen the plastic army men and said “There has to be a game there”? Well I asked myself that often and finally took the plunge and wrote one. Originally the game was only army men but I couldn’t resist the idea of using cowboys, Indians, and for some odd reason, firemen. After all we are already playing with plastic dudes, we can include them all!

The basic idea here is to go to the Dollar store, spend less than $10 and have a fun miniatures game for two people. This doesn't include terrain of course. I recommend playing at the FLGS! (buy something when you are there)

All the units are put into a bag and mixed up. The first player pulls a guy out of the bag and decides if he wants to keep him or reject him. Rejected units form a pile (not returned to the bag). If you keep certain units you get a bonus draw (if you keep an Indian you can draw a bonus guy from the bag or from the reject pile). The next player than can pick a unit from the bag OR the reject pile, if they pick from the reject pile they also get a second unit from the reject pile on top of any bonuses the first unit gives. So if I took an Indian from the reject pile I’d get to take another unit from the pile AND a unit from the bag or pile, the bonus units do not give extra units however)

Terrain is placed, units are placed near the edge of the table and it’s time to play. Basically it goes like this. Both guys flip cards from a deck, face cards are set aside, when the total you flipped equals 10 or more they stop. The total is the number of 6 sided dice they get for the turn. These are assigned to the individual units. Army men can have a maximum of 3 dice for example.

Now players take turns. On your turn you activate one unit. That unit then spends at least one die. The dice are used to move, shoot or perform special actions. Moving units are subject to opportunity fire, units performing opportunity fire are subject to covering fire. Of course these actions cost dice, and that limits what else they can do. Dice are indeed a precious commodity!

Remember those removed face cards? They are used to activate special powers and leadership powers. Your special power is determined by what the majority of your units are. Mainly army men? You get the artillery strike! Mainly Cowboys? You get the high noon duel! Leadership powers include healing, damage reduction and group fire. Another tough decision is how to spend those face cards!

The round ends when all the dice are spent. First check to see if any unit has died (taken enough wounds). Yes you don’t realize you are dead until the end of the round. Well you can be killed outright during the round but you get to spend all your dice on a retaliatory strike! No dice are wasted! (except for all those ones I rolled) Next you check victory, if you roll a singe d6 and its higher then the total number of guys you have left your army runs away! It’s possible that both armies run away on the same turn. Then no one wins, or both people do, fight about it.

name: Fruit Flies
description: Players each receive a starting card that has three elements: a number, a color and a fruit. Everyone tries to win three more cards that each match a different element of their initial card. The tricky bit is this: to claim a card, you must be the first to cover it up with your hand. But then you must recall the three elements on the card in order without peeking.
mechanics: Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Schachadma
description:
Schachadma (from "schach", meaning chess, and "adma", short for admiral) by Klaus W. Schomberg is a chess family game played on a 12x12 board, inspired by chess and battleships.

Each piece is a ship, with between one and four masts. Each turn, a player moves or rotates a ship, after which all of that ship's cannons fire. Enemy masts within range of the cannons are captured; when a ship has no masts left, it is also captured.

The tallest mast on the largest ship represents the admiral; capturing an opponent's admiral wins the game.

name: Arcane Legions: Dragons of the Far East
description:
From the box:

From the forests of China and the rivers of Japan come two of Asia's mightiest creatures. Command the fearsome power of China's royal Forest Dragons and harness the chaotic nature of the Japanese river spirits known as Luck Dragons, both available in this single box.
categories: Ancient, Collectible Components, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Mythology

name: Tiananmen
description:
This is an asymetric pure strategy game based on the events at Tiananmen Square in 1989. One player (black) plays the Chinese Communist Party. Their goal is to surround the Monument to the People's Heroes. The students (white) must link from the Monument to the outside world.

The game is played on a standard go board with go stones.

name: Colossal Cave: The Board Game – Back Promo
description:
Promo card for Colossal Cave: The Board Game given exclusively to backers of the Kickstarter campaign. The card name is "BACK". The card can only be played at the end of any player's turn. That player's pawn will then be moved back to the room in which it started the turn.

Notice that "BACK" is a "Reaction" card ("Play out of turn when..."), even though it was misprinted with the red "Action" icon.

name: Pskov Checkers
description:
As HexDame is a hexagonal adaptation of International Checkers, Pskov Checkers (or Pskovskie Shashki) is a Checkers Family game adapted to a hexagonal board, in this case probably Shashki, though no inventor or date of creation is currently known.

Pskov Checkers can be played on one of two boards, both of them regular hexagons comprised of hexagonal cells. The smaller board consists of 37 cells, four to each side of the larger hexagon. The larger board consists of 61 cells, five to each of the larger hexagon’s sides. Both boards are set between two players with a point closest to each player. On the smaller board, each player has 13 pieces, arranged on every cell of their half of the board, with a row of vacant cells in the middle. Likewise on the larger board, but with 24 pieces per player.

Other than the varying boards and arrangement of pieces, the difference between Pskov and Shashki is in the promotion of pieces; in Pskov Checkers, pieces can only be promoted on the farthest corner cell, closest to the opponent, rather than the furthest row as in Hexdame.

name: GI Joe Micro Force
description:
Micro Force is a (very) light game to promote Hasbro's range of super deformed "chibi" GI Joe miniatures. Each miniature is 28mm high and comes with a round stand. Players should toss the stands at each others miniatures and tip them all over.
Hasbro's main priority obviously was selling the miniatures and designing a solid game behind it came second. They didn't even add the usual dice, it's just throwing small discs at the opponent's GI Joes or Cobras. But hey! Aren't those miniatures super awesome!!!

So, great components but maybe not much of a "game", even when Hasbro says it is :)

name: Ancient Colonies
description:
In this board game of ancient Greek and Phoenician colonization in the 8th to 7th centuries BCE, pilot your ship of colonists to an undiscovered Italian shore and establish colonies in fortuitous locations. Settle as soon as possible or pursue the ideal location. Establish close to others to enhance trade, or remain safe and remote. Re-invest to grow your colonies or pursue those of others. Send your ship home or use it in the new waters. Create more colonies or thrive safely behind strong walls. Negotiate the path between speedy growth and the disruption it causes.

A war game of building up a civilization including a modular board, variable powers and a rich set of heavily-researched cards providing special powers.
categories: Ancient, Civilization, Economic, Exploration, Print & Play, Wargame
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Modular Board, Point to Point Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: Stawiam na kolej
description:
Stawiam na kolej is a strategic and economic board game.
This game not only entertains, but also educates. The players (2 to 4) are investors who buy shares of Polish railway companies.
Companies are building a rail network, carrying a variety of tasks.
Players who own shares of companies benefit from these investments.
At the end of the game rail network is fully developed. The player who undertook the best investment decisions and earned the most wins the game.
---
Strategiczno-ekonomiczna gra planszowa „Stawiam na kolej” nie tylko bawi, ale też edukuje. Gracze (od 2 do 4) wcielają się w niej w inwestorów, którzy kupują udziały polskich spółek kolejowych. Spółki budują sieć kolejową, realizując różne zadania, np. „Zmodernizuj linię Wrocław – Zielona Góra, zelektryfikuj ją”. Gracze, którzy są właścicielami udziałów spółek, czerpią zyski z tych inwestycji. Na koniec gry sieć kolejowa jest całkowicie rozwinięta. Gracz, który podejmował najlepsze decyzje inwestycyjne i zarobił najwięcej, zostaje zwycięzcą gry.
mechanics: Network and Route Building, Stock Holding

name: Floor It!
description:
From the back of the box:

Floor It! is very easy to play. Players choose the number of laps to race and then move around the track by choosing one of three card types - Floor It!, Cruise, or Take It Easy.

The game is a trade-off between speed and safety. Each player must decide how they will drive in order to safely navigate the course. It is safest when driving in a straight section of the course. The greatest danger is when driving in a corner. A driver who decides to go fast or "floor it" is more likely to crash than a driver who chooses to "take it easy".

name: Battle of Berserk
description:
User summary:

A 2 player card driven battle game based on the manga with the same name by Kentaro Miura.

Players draw 5 cards from a common deck; cards are numbered 0–5. Each player puts down a card, and in turn, turn them face up to either move as many spaces as the card shows or attack (if the distance to the enemy is as many spaces as the card shows) and then puts down another card. Hence moves are programmed one turn in advance.

The first player to inflict 2 damage wins. The game also has special character cards, and some rule-changing cards to draw at random if players want to spice up the game.

name: Pile o' Bones
description:
You and your associates have been given the task of moving the remains of four families from the local cemetery to a new one, but due to laziness, incompetence, and a general lack of morals, the contents have “shifted” during shipping and you’re left with a big pile o’ bones.

The families’ living relatives have agreed not to press charges against the first person to sort and put to rest the bones of one entire family. Of course, being an unscrupulous lot, you’ve agreed that “mostly right” is good enough…

Pile o' Bones is a simple yet deep family card game where each player is trying to put their family of four to rest.

A player only needs to own a majority of the bones in a completed skeleton to claim it. Players may draw new bones randomly from the bone pile hoping to get what they need or they may strategically break apart and move a partially constructed skeleton.

Once a skeleton is completed, whoever owns the majority of the bones claims it as one of their family's members and puts them to rest.

name: Monopoly: Classic Volkswagen Collectors Edition
description:
It's Monopoly for Volkswagen enthusiasts! Same as original Monopoly, with all of the board spaces, cards, tokens, etc. done over with an air cooled Volkswagen theme.

Instead of buying property you are buying classic VW vehicles instead. Houses are now Carports and Hotels are Garages. Road Map and Full Tank cards replace Chance and Community Chest. Gas Stations replace the Train Stations.

Includes 6 collectible pewter tokens: Key, Steering Wheel, Peace Sign, Surfboards (on a roof rack), Gas Can, and a Bud Vase.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading
publishers: The Op Games, Winning Moves Germany

name: Beamstrike
description:
A free science fiction miniatures skirmish game. From the rules introduction:

"Beamstrike - The miniatures game - is a set of fast paced, simple, science fiction war-game rules for tabletop battles using 15mm model miniature figures. A wide range of armoured vehicles can be fielded, from Tanks, to Walkers and Mecha. Rules for alien races, including generic ‘bugs’ and ‘greys’, add interest, and full rules allowing robots and androids complete the sci-fi repertoire."

name: Gaffes & Promises
description:
Gaffes & Promises is a card drafting game featuring events from the 2013 Australian Federal Election. Players represent political parties trying to garner votes using promises and subjecting their opponents to gaffes.

Over three rounds, players draft cards with varying support for four demographics: Families, Students, Pensioners and Big Business. Three demographic cards are in play per round, and the player with the most support in each at the end of a round wins that card. The player with the most demographic cards at the end of the game is the winner.

name: Airport Football
description:
Tired of "Tic-Tac-Toe" and "Hangman"? Try Pencil Football (a.k.a. Airport Football)! It's a paper and pencil game for 1 or 2 players simulating a game of American Football. All you need to play is something to write on and something to write with. That means it's free!

The game is played in 4 quarters. Each quarter consists of a player taking a turn on offense and on defense. Offense always starts at their opponent's 35 yard line.

Offense: You have 4 downs to score. Write the appropriate letters in a 6-digit code to represent your play:
Run = three 'R's
Pass = two 'P's
Hail-Mary = three 'P's
Field Goal = one, two, or three 'F's (depending on field position: >30, 10 - 30, <10 yard line)

Defense: Without seeing your opponent's play, choose 3 distinct numbers between 1 and 6. These are the left-to-right digits in the offense's play that you block this down.

A run is successful and moves the offense 10 yards if at least two 'R's are unblocked.
A pass is successful and moves the offense 20 yards if both 'P's are unblocked.
A hail-mary is successful and results in an instant touchdown if all 3 'P's are unblocked.
A field goal is successful if at least 1 'F' is unblocked.

If you score a touchdown you can attempt a field goal from the 5 yard line or attempt a 2-point conversion from the 5 yard line.

name: Space Spinners
description:
Players in Space Spinners need to be the first to load their fuel payload into the spaceship because if they do, they'll be the one to launch the ship and win.

Each player has five colored fuel balls, a landing pad, and a "spinner ship". With everyone playing at once, players place one or more fuel balls on their landing pad, place their spinner ship over these balls, then moves their ship in circles so quickly that centrifugal force holds the balls up and doesn't let them fall through the hole in the bottom of the spinner ship. Place your ship on top of the mother ship and let your fuel balls fall inside; if someone else places a spinner on top of yours, you're pinned until their fuel is loaded, so you want to get in and out as quickly as possible — but that's tricky to do because if you don't spin your ship quickly, your fuel will eject before you've reached the mother ship!

If you drop a ball, you pick it up, then place it on your landing pad later for another go. Whoever loads her fuel first wins!

name: Tomoe
description:
Tomoe represents the struggle between black and white.
Both players try to encircle with their colour areas as large as they can, without being encircled by the opponents' colour themselves.

The game consists of a board and 32 triple hexagon tiles (4 different tiles, 8 of each).

Players alternately place tiles on the board and eventually also rotate a tile already on the board.
As all tiles contain black and white areas, you can not just build your own area, but always also build something for your opponent. So you have to be very careful what you do, as an enclosed area only counts to your score if it is not enclosed by your opponent itself.

The game ends as soon as the whole board is occupied.
Players count the sectors of their opponents colour in areas they have encircled. The player with the highest score wins.

name: MERCS: Recon – Blood Contagion
description:
The Blood Contagion Mission Pack adds the Infected to MERCS: Recon

Infected in Recon are experiments that have gone bad. They are considered to be Employees. If they are killed, civilian penalties apply. However, Infected do not try to leave the building like other Employees. They seek out and attack other OpFor and MERCS.

The Infected have a chance to turn other OpFor into Infected. Infected OpFor are replaced with special Infected OpFor cards and are marked with a token. Infected OpFor have altered priorities and do different things. The mini-campaign in Blood Contagion revolves around the MERCS going deep into a lab, finding the cure, not letting the Infected get out-of-hand, and saving as many Infected as possible.

Additionally, the Infected bring with them a completely new way for the MERCS to lose: if ever there are 15 Infected in the structure the MERCS have been defeated.

This Mission Pack is a Myth Crossover. The Infected can also be used as Minions in Myth.

The Infected Minions are tough to kill. They have 3 Vitality. On a successful attack, the Infected roll a 1FD. If the Infected rolls the Darkness symbol, the Hero cannot produce treasure. Additionally, if that Hero while infected becomes adjacent to other Heroes, then the infected Hero rolls 1FD for each Hero adjacent. If the roll matches the defining attribute, then the adjacent Hero becomes infected and can no longer generate treasure either.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Science Fiction
mechanics: Action Points, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Variable Player Powers

name: Big Fun Battle
description: In Big Fun Battle, players use their earth, water, wind, wood, and fire cards to attack one another and guess one another's line-up.

name: Star Worlds CCG
description:
Star Worlds is a collectible card game, where a player takes a role of a commander of a space fleet.

A player starts the game with a base and 50-card deck. The base can produce certain types of units, which in turn can produce other types of units. In addition to this a player can play characters and put light spaceships directly into play from his or her hand.

Spaceships can be divided into many categories: some of them can attack other spaceships, other recover used cards or cover key units from enemy fire, deliver ammunition onto the battlefield.

Once a player has gathered enough units, he or she can attack their opponent’s base. If the player’s base is destroyed, the other player wins the game. Another way to win the game is to collect twelve strategic points, produced by strategic objects. The third way includes the defense of the base until the opponent will run out of cards in their deck.

The creator and designer of the game is Vladimir Kravchenko.

The first set consists from 110 cards, 55 for each of two factions.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Card Game, Collectible Components, Science Fiction

name: Zpocalypse: Aftermath – Totalbisquit
description: Totalbiscuit A.K.A the Cynical Brit, is a refined English gentleman of acerbic wit and regal authority. His commentary on video games was watched by millions, but with the collapse of civilization, Biscuit sought a new vocation. He can only assume that slaughtering zombies will prove less frustrating than some of the video games he’s played.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Exploration, Fighting, Horror, Miniatures, Zombies
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Open Drafting

name: Zpocalypse: Aftermath – Linkara
description: Mild-mannered comic book reviewer Linkara has always found himself in world-threatening crises. Armed with an indomitable will, quick wits, a star ship, and an arsenal of hi-tech and magical weapons, he triumphed. But not even Linkara could stop the coming of the Zpocalypse.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Exploration, Fighting, Horror, Miniatures, Zombies
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Open Drafting

name: Zpocalypse: Aftermath – Jim Sterling
description: Fancy man about town Jim Sterling was once the celebrated reviews editor of Destructoid.com, as well as a consumer advocate on the Jimquisition. A man of controversial opinion, Jim was no stranger to being attacked by mindless hordes, even before the zombie outbreak occurred. With an imposing frame that belies his uncanny agility, Jim joins up with Angry Joe to get the undead sorted out once and for all.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Exploration, Fighting, Horror, Miniatures, Zombies
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hand Management

name: Zpocalypse: Aftermath – Dr. Insano
description: When internet film and game critic Spoony succumbs to madness, he becomes a creature of chaos and science: Doctor Insano! Approached by his arch-enemies, Angry Joe and Linkara, the mad scientist agrees to help fight the zombie threat – if only so he can destroy the world himself!
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Horror, Zombies

name: Star Trek: Attack Wing – Tholian Web Organized Play tokens
description:
Guide tokens and Energy web tokens for playing the Tholian Web Organized Play Scenario.

Description from the scenario:
"While responding to a distress signal in an uncharted sector, you quickly learn that it was a trap and find yourself engaged in combat with enemy ships. Unbeknownst to both fleets, your battle has taken you into an annex of the Tholian Assembly and Tholian ships have begun weaving a deadly energy web around your fleets. Your only chance to survive is to defeat your enemy before the web is completed and hope that your remaining ships can escape the powerful draw of the Tholian Web."
categories: Aviation / Flight, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction
mechanics: Action Queue, Player Elimination, Point to Point Movement

name: Tanden: A Game From Hara
description:
Win the game by being the first player to have a total of 10 worth of rifts out on the board.

On each turn, players draw a card from a central deck and take three actions including changing from which color of crystal they can derive power, playing a card from their hand, or drawing another card. Rift cards are used to score points and monster cards attack and defend rift cards.

name: Thrash-Car: Collector's Edition
description:
The Collector's Edition of Thrash-Car includes 8 extra action cards, 4 extra race car tokens, and 2 extra team placards (4 teams) that have had foil applied to them. Action cards and team placards have unique actions and abilities.

The Collector's Edition box also has an Embossed foil stamp on the cover and is signed and numbered. There will only be 300 units of this version ever manufactured.


In Thrash-Car, you build your racing team from the ground up. As the team owner, you choose your crew, car, and strategy, then help them drive their way to victory in some of the wildest and toughest race conditions you have ever seen.

Each driver is trying to get around the track and survive it. The track is made of random cards drawn from the track deck, and each card has a target attribute, a target number, and a damage value. The attribute determines that base attribute from your car you are using to build your base roll modifier. The target number is the number you have to roll on a ten-sided die or greater to succeed and move to the next track space. Damage is how much damage your car takes if you fail your roll.

When you go to move, the other drivers can play up to one card on your action stack (this is the screw your neighbor part). The draw deck plays one card, then you can play up to two on yourself. These cards will result in a modifier for your roll to move. You add or subtract that number from your car's base and roll the die. If you make the target you move ahead and keep racing; if you fail you take the listed damage and try to keep racing. Fail too many rolls, and your car will be destroyed. You are always trying to get ahead and your friends are always trying to drag you down.

At times, the drivers can beat on each other with their cars and roll head-to-head to see who is better in these exchanges, but if you get outrolled you can take some serious damage. If you do the outrolling, though, you can hammer the other guy and leap ahead in the race.

You win Thrash-Car by being the first to complete the designated laps or being the last car running on the track.

name: Flippin' Fruit: Tropical Expansion
description:
First expansion to Flippin' Fruit.

The Tropical Expansion includes:

16 NEW Smoothie cards
4 NEW Fruit Basket cards
1 Tropical Fruit Die

name: Fields of Gore
description:
In the world of Lyzarbhy the magic, chaos and the adventure welcomes you !

Fields of Gore is the introductory set for FOG game system edition. It is a basic set game containing forces of Orcs and Undead with a small rulebook, scenario book, paper templates, paper models, paper miniatures necessary to play. Set during The Great Orcoid Wars in the world of Lyzarbhi.

This PNP set contains two starter armies plus a scenario, player aids and redux rules of FOG system.

Players take command of each force, fighting a sample scenario and the rulebook have rules for create another ones, with a simplified points system.

With a rich lore and a lot of fluff, the game give to the players lot of fun without tons of rules.

name: Franky Reloaded
description:
Franky is back!
In a secret laboratory, the players try to assemble as many Frankies as possible and then activate them with lightning flashes. Only energy charged Frankies can score in the game.
Not every Franky is the same, the risky ’small’ red Frankies can win the most victory points ..

excerpt of the official rules:
The object of the game is to win 12 victory points or more. The highest number of victory points wins the game. In case of a tie of victory points a flash-duel (between the affected players) takes place in a special round. Note: Victory point is a funny reference to the fictional character Victor Frankenstein.
How to play: Each game round the player has a regular dice turn with multiple number of rolls. After each roll, any number of dice can be laid aside, but at least 1 die is always required! Dice which are laid aside cannot be re-rolled in this round. At the end of the regular dice turn (all dice are laid aside) the result is evaluated. A lightning flash symbolizes a victory point, but only if the player can assemble a complete Franky in a same color (2 other dice in green or according violet). A green or violet Franky is always assembled with a head and a body.
Note: If you want to achieve a regular victory point this way, always 3 dice are necessary.
Red Frankies: After the player has completed his regular dice turn (all dice are laid aside), all red Frankies are rolled once again. Here the player has gained special chances with these dice. A red Franky can immediately achieve victory points if he shows a flash after the rolling (the red Franky has been activated). Here no assembly with other dice is required because the red Franky is already complete (custom-made). Displays the die (after the roll) again a red Franky, he will be re-rolled again, all other symbols do not help anymore.
Note: If the player wins victory points this way, only 1 single die is necessary. Depending on how many red Frankies the player has laid aside, a lot of victory points can be earned.

excerpt of the official rules Blue Eyes (included first expansion):
The player can try to score victory points as usual. If he plays a total of victory points that is similar with the number the blue spot die shows, the victory points can be doubled. Note: The player can decide to devaluate any number of victory points to fulfill the spot die (only
complete activated Frankies can be devaluated).







Franky ist zurück!
Im geheimen Labor versuchen die Spieler möglichst viele Frankys zusammenzubauen und diese dann mit Energieblitzen zu aktivieren. Nur energiegeladene Frankys können im Spiel punkten.
Nicht jeder Franky ist gleich, die riskanten „kleinen” roten Frankys können die meisten Siegpunkte erspielen ..

Auszug des offiziellen Regelwerks:
Spielziel sind 12 Siegpunkte oder mehr. Die höchste Anzahl an Siegpunkten gewinnt das Spiel. Bei Gleichstand von Siegpunkten wird ein Blitz-Duell in einer Sonderrunde ausgetragen.
Spielüberblick: Pro Spielrunde hat der Spieler einen regulären Würfeldurchgang mit mehreren Würfen. Nach jedem Wurf können beliebig viele Würfel rausgelegt werden, mindestens 1 Würfel ist aber immer Pflicht! Rausgelegte Würfel können in dieser Runde nicht wieder neu mitgewürfelt werden. Erst am Ende des regulären Würfeldurchgangs (alle Würfel sind rausgelegt) wird das Ergebnis gewertet. Ein Energieblitz bedeutet einen Siegpunkt, welcher aber erst durch den Zusammenbau von einem Franky in einer gleichen Farbe (2 andere Würfel in grün oder entsprechend violett) gewertet werden kann. Ein grüner oder violetter Franky wird immer zusammengebaut mit Kopf und Rumpf.
Hinweis: Soll auf diese Weise ein regulärer Siegpunkt erzielt werden, sind dafür immer 3 Würfel notwendig.
Rote Frankys: Nachdem der Spieler seinen regulären Würfeldurchgang abgeschlossen hat (alle Würfel sind rausgelegt), werden alle roten Frankys einmalig erneut gewürfelt; der Spieler hat sich bei diesen Würfeln Sonderchancen erspielt. Ein roter Franky kann sofort Siegpunkte erzielen, wenn er jetzt nach dem würfeln einen Energieblitz zeigt (der rote Franky wurde aktiviert). Hier ist kein Zusammenbau mit anderen Würfeln erforderlich, da die roten Frankys schon komplett sind (Sonderanfertigungen). Zeigt der Würfel (nach dem würfeln) erneut einen roten Franky, wird dieser als Wiederholung erneut gewürfelt, alle anderen Symbole bringen nichts mehr.
Hinweis: Sollen also so Siegpunkte erspielt werden, ist hierfür nur 1 einziger Würfel notwendig. Auf diese Weise können beliebig viele Siegpunkte erspielt werden, je nachdem wie viele rote Frankys der Spieler rausgelegt hat.

Auszug des offiziellen Regelwerks Blue Eyes (enthaltene erste Erweiterung):
Der Spieler kann ganz normal auf Siegpunkte spielen. Schafft er es jedoch genau so viele Siegpunkte zu erspielen, wie der Augenwürfel zeigt, können die Siegpunkte verdoppelt werden.
Hinweis: Der Spieler kann sich entscheiden Siegpunkte verfallen zu lassen (nur komplett aktivierte Frankys können verfallen), damit der Augenwürfel erfüllt werden kann.

name: The Glorious Fall
description:
The Glorious Fall is a dynamic, competitive/cooperative game with minimized luck. It recreates the entire epic lifespan of the Byzantine Empire, from the founding by Constantine the Great to its last gasp (or not, if you manage to keep it intact).

During play your Dynasty will be given a choice of secret destinies, such as keeping the empire alive, destroying it, or controlling the Basileus through two consecutive Eras, etc., and a number of Byzantine Plot cards to use when you choose. The map consists of the Themes of the Empire, with three "resources" contained in each: people, religious ferver, and commerce.

The game is won by the family accumulating the most Glory Points by the end of the final era in any combination of three ways: fulfilling your Dynasty's unique, secret destinies, developing the Themes (regions) within the empire, and shaping the empire to suit your purposes while denying other's their revealed plans.

Your family will dominate various roles throughout the game: Basileus (Emperor), Logothete (Administrator), Patriarch, Strategos (General), or Katepano (control the mobs of Constantinople). Each title grants limited political power, forcing cooperation, but each can seize unlimited political power at various times when Byzantine Plots are revealed and anyone can suddenly seize control of the Basileus' actions, or even the throne itself.

Roles switch when players reveal plots of various strengths by using Byzantine Plot cards. In essence assassinating the Emperor in favor of their own candidate; misleading an Army sent to defend Jerusalem, convincing it to go to Cilicia instead; or denying the Basileus the power to hand out political favors, instead forcing him to divide the power as your dynasty sees fit.

Each family (player) has only so much political power to expend at any time, and must choose when to intervene and when to let the Basileus (or another family) have their way.

Throughout the game, the Empire faces Barbarian invasions from its borders, and possible rebellions from within. Players will create alliances that may last or end before ever begun as nefarious plots are revealed. The Basileus may see Crusades or merchant enclaves rise up to restore parts of the Empire or betray the Empire and sack the Queen of Cities.
categories: Bluffing, Civilization, Economic, Medieval, Political, Territory Building
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Auction/Bidding, Cooperative Game, Variable Player Powers

name: Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey: Crops Expansion Deck B
description:
From the publisher:

In the ultimate race to build a bunny society on planet Earth, Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey pits players against each other as they struggle to gain Civilization Points, by building cities and increasing their bunny populations. Players gain points by developing their own civilizations or by using zany weapons and hilarious scenarios to destroy their opponents.

The Green deck has a Crops-based theme which also includes fruits, vegetables and marvelous cards such as Transplanted Troop which allows players to steal bunnies and Reversal Of Order which helps dictate the order of card play!
categories: Card Game, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Humor
mechanics: Deck Construction, Dice Rolling, Hand Management

name: Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey: Land Expansion Deck B
description:
From the publisher:

In the ultimate race to build a bunny society on planet Earth, Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey pits players against each other as they struggle to gain Civilization Points, by building cities and increasing their bunny populations. Players gain points by developing their own civilizations or by using zany weapons and hilarious scenarios to destroy their opponents.

The Yellow deck has a Land based theme which also includes deserts, forests and remarkable cards such as Crossroads which dictates bunny attacks and Urban Plague which can empty your opponent’s cities immediately!
categories: Card Game, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Humor
mechanics: Deck Construction, Dice Rolling, Hand Management

name: Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey: Animals Expansion Deck B
description:
From the publisher:

In the ultimate race to build a bunny society on planet Earth, Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey pits players against each other as they struggle to gain Civilization Points, by building cities and increasing their bunny populations. Players gain points by developing their own civilizations or by using zany weapons and hilarious scenarios to destroy their opponents.

The Orange deck has an Animals based theme which also includes mammals, marsupials and incredible cards such as We Are The World which gives maximum Civ Point rewards for city building and Cruel Mule which can deflect an attack!
categories: Animals, Card Game, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Humor
mechanics: Deck Construction, Dice Rolling, Hand Management

name: Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey: Technology Expansion Deck B
description:
From the publisher:

In the ultimate race to build a bunny society on planet Earth, Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey pits players against each other as they struggle to gain Civilization Points, by building cities and increasing their bunny populations. Players gain points by developing their own civilizations or by using zany weapons and hilarious scenarios to destroy their opponents.

The Blue deck has a Technology based theme which also includes devices, robots and fantastic cards such as All Bits Zero which allows a player to exchange his cards and Encore, Encore which deals a double deadly blow!
mechanics: Deck Construction, Dice Rolling, Hand Management

name: Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey: Elementals Expansion Deck B
description:
From the publisher:

In the ultimate race to build a bunny society on planet Earth, Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey pits players against each other as they struggle to gain Civilization Points, by building cities and increasing their bunny populations. Players gain points by developing their own civilizations or by using zany weapons and hilarious scenarios to destroy their opponents.

The Violet deck has an Elemental based theme which also includes metals, jewels and amazing cards such as Slow Smelting which causes players to lose their turn and Maybe, Maybe Not which can eliminate an opponent’s attack!
categories: Card Game, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Humor
mechanics: Deck Construction, Dice Rolling, Hand Management

name: Shinsei Maougun
description:
A new Demon King has been crowned. The players are summoners competing for his approval by summoning demons and hiring human followers to strengthen the king's army and conquer the human realm.

Players use a combination of resources to pay for either demon or human cards. These cards are used to produce more resources to obtain more powerful minions and to attack human cities on the board in return for gold and the approval of the Demon King.

The game lasts for six rounds. At the end of the sixth round, the player with the most victory points (a combination of approval points and gold) is the winner. The game also includes special rules for solo play.

name: The Sci or Fi Files
description:
Test your knowledge of science truths with this set of 480 strange science statements! Includes 200 double-sided cards with fun facts and scientific explanations 32 score chips and 18 answer cards in file-cabinet box. For 2–6 players. Grades 5+

How to Play:

1. Take turns reading 3 science statements.

2. Everyone guesses which one is true or which one is false.

3. Turn the card over to find out—along with an explanation about each true or false fact to read aloud.

4. Collect one score chip from each category to win.

name: Kaiju Conquest
description:
Kaiju Conquest is a strategy wargame depicting the battle for Earth in 2116 AD, with the First Inter-Species War between the humans of the United Earth Reaction Force (UERF), and the reptilian Sazzarran Empire.

The objective of the game is to have the most Victory Points based on control of damaged or non-damaged city and land zones by the end of game round five.

The initial invasion began in the Pacific Ocean and its bordering coastlines, which is also portrayed on the game board. There are 15 major coastal city zones and 7 land zones, which were involved in the war of the Pacific Campaign. The cities are beautifully illustrated by the artist, Becca T-R.

The game contains eight Mecha characters of eight different designs well as 8 kaiju characters of eight different species, including the Warlord, who is the Supreme Commander of the Sazarran invasion force. Fighting along with and supporting the mecha are Army, Air Force, Navy and Marine forces combined into a common Military Unit (MU). The Sazzarran have their own version of Army, Air, Sea and other special units, also combined as a Military Unit. The UERF also have access to nukes and the Sazzarran have bio-bombs.

There are five game rounds. In each game round the players will receive a fixed number of Resource Points to build their MUs and respective Mecha and Kaiju. Each game round the Resource Points are two points less than the previous game round, starting with 15 points and ending with seven points. At the beginning of each game round, the players may also have received extra Resource Points by destroying the opposing players forces.

There are five phases during each game round.
1. Maintenance Phase: One of the players will move the hexagonal game round token to the next game round hex space. Both sides will then collect the number of Resource Points (RPs) as shown below the current game round number.

2. Draw Phase: Both sides randomly draw six cards from their respective Tactic Card decks. These cards can be used during the Draw, Resource, Movement and Battle Phases to give bonuses respectively to each of those phases. The Sazzarran player then draws four Target Zone Cards. These cards display a particular city, a land or a sea zone. The Sazzarran player chooses two of the cards and the other two are discarded under the Target Zone deck. The two chosen cards will be the zones where the Sazzarran MUs and Kaiju will deploy.

3. Resource Phase: The UERF will purchase their MECHA and MUs as well as any Nukes for the current game round, based on the number of RPs available. The Sazzarran will also be purchasing their Kaiju and MUs. The Sazzarran will also be deciding which zones the Kaiju and MUs will deployed into during the Movement Phase.

4. Movement Phase: The Sazzarran deploys their forces first at the designated target zones. If there are any UERF units in the zones, the Sazzarran must leave one MU for each UERF MU in the zone. Mecha and Kaiju can freely move between zones within their movement allowance, unless there is an opposing Mecha or Kaiju in the zone. If the zone is unoccupied, the Sazzarran can split up their Kaiju and MUs to take more zones in an attempt to damage and potentially destroy the cities and land zones.

Once the Sazzarran has moved any or all of their units, the UERF counter moves their forces to a zone occupied by Sazzarran forces. Both sides may also attempt to blockade each other using the city, land and especially seas zones, to block movement from one zone to another.

5. Battle Phase: The players will battle for control of city, land, and sea zones. Each battle in a contested zone results in total elimination of an opposing force, unless they choose to withdraw after each battle round in that zone. All contested zones must be resolved with a battle. Once the last battle is fought, the game round ends. At the end of each battle in a zone, the players will receive Resource Points based on the build cost of the opposing unit destroyed. These Resource Points are tracked on the players Resource Trackers on their side of the game board.

At the end of game round five, the players will calculate their Victory Points (VPs. The Sazzarran receive one VP for each damage point on a city or land zone. The UERF receive one VP for each city or land zone that still have any Zone Points (ZPs) remaining. Both sides receive a VP for each zone occupied by at least one of their units. Both sides also receive VPs equal to the number of RPs they have remaining on their respective Resource Point Tracker. The side with the most Victory Points wins the game and will most likely have control of the Pacific Ocean and its coastal cities and land zones.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Moving Multiple Units, Team-Based Game

name: Star Trek: Attack Wing – I.K.S. T'Ong Expansion Pack
description:
The I.K.S. T’Ong is a Klingon K’t’inga-class battle-cruiser that was sent by the Klingon High Command on a long-range mission in the year 2290. Returning from the mission, Captain K’Temoc and the crew of the T’Ong woke from a cryogenic stasis 75 years in the future. They encountered the U.S.S. Enterprise-D and learned that the Federation-Klingon War had ended.
Star Trek - Attack Wing: I.K.S. T'Ong Expansion Pack is part of the Wave 17 expansion packs from WizKids Games, and this expansion comes with one new ship and a new set of cards for Star Trek: Attack Wing.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Miniatures, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction
mechanics: Action Queue, Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers

name: Europa
description:
Europa is a Reversi variant.

Materials
8x8 checkerboard
64 Othello disks

Play
Board starts out empty.

One player plays black the other white.

Decide who goes first in any convenient manner, turns then alternate.

The game is played in two phases.

In the first phase on a turn, you must,

1) Place a friendly color disk in an empty space that is not orthogonally adjacent to an opponent's color disk (diagonally adjacent is fine) or

2) Pass.

The game enters the second phase after players pass consecutively.

So from now on, on a turn, either,

1) Place a disk of your color on an empty space or

2) Place a disk on an empty space so that it and another like color disk already on the board enclose a line of one or more
disks of your opponent. Then flip the disks to your color. A line of enclosed disks may run horizontally, vertically or diagonally.

The game ends when the board is full.

Object
The player with the most disks in his color on the board wins.

name: Salvage Crew
description:
From the rulebook:

You are a Star Mogul and the owner of a newly formed Salvage Crew. The outer rim is a treasure trove of lost
or abandoned property. Your mission is to stake your claim by force if necessary to these forgotten riches.

Salvage Crew: Star Mogul is a set of rules for use with the 25mm and 15mm scale, table-top sci-fi war games miniatures manufactured by Mega Miniatures.
categories: Adventure, Fighting, Miniatures, Print & Play, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: World War 2 Wargaming
description:
Airfix Magazine Guide 15, written in an informal style, as much an exploration of how to create a wargame, and what it simulates, this small book includes all data needed for a detailed, traditional miniatures system, as well as extensive discussion on why the author made the decisions he did in it's creation. Extensive charts & tables cover point-buy options, movement rates with terrain effects, sighting ranges, armour values (with multiple locations per vehicle) and gun penetration, etc.

The chosen figure scale is 1/72 (to include 1/76), while the miniature to real life ration of 1:1 makes this skirmish scale gaming.

Illustrations through the book are pictures of miniatures and wargames in progress. Original price was £1.40!
categories: Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Trka oldtajmera
description:
Oldtimer race is a very simple game for 2 to 4 players.

Each player has one oldtimer car. All cars drive around the city and collect counters by stopping on field next to it. The winner is the player who collects the most counters.

name: More Curses!
description:
From the publisher:

Fifty new side splitting Curses that will make you beg for more and 50 new crazy "challenge cards" that are easy to do but hard to watch without laughing. Also 8 NEW Ding Cards! You can mix the new curses with the original curses decks and use it with the original rules or you can play More Curses as a stand alone game. Whatever you do keep playing and keep laughing; it's good for you.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Card Game, Humor, Party Game

name: Rumble
description: Rumble is a customizable discard game, where the goal of the game is to get rid of all your cards before your opponents and become the RUMBLE MASTER! There are 90 cards in a RUMBLE deck and contains 10 different RUMBLER cards in 4 colors (red, blue, green, and yellow) and 10 wild RAINBOW CARDS. By adding expansions called "RUMBLE PACKS" it’s possible to create your own custom games with brand new RUMBLERS to do battle with!

name: Home Raiders
description:
Home Raiders is a game played with small scale models. These models represent the combatants that travel from a dimension known as the Inner-space to your very home, in order to battle for the dominance of your space. These fighters are little folk (which means that the scale of the models is actually 1:1) which exist in dimensions parallel to ours, and crash our world in order to thrive in theirs.

The basic game is very easy to grasp, and is a great option for a fast game that takes place in your actual living room coffee table, your office desk, or even around your kitchen sink. It takes no time at all to set up, so you can get your dice rolling in a breeze. If you are an experienced gamer, Home Raiders is a great choice for an improvised gaming session or even a well laid out match amongst a bunch of friends. If you want to play with your younger brothers and sisters, cousins or even your children, you won't find a better option to getting them started with this amazing hobby.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Variable Player Powers

name: Archimago
description:
The Archmage is dying... a successor must be found from the 4 schools of magic, so a contest is afoot. The Principal of the school with the most Prestige will be the next Archmage.

Each player controls 10 wizards of one of the 4 different schools (on the base game they would be fire, earth, water & air). In the beginning players start with 4 wizards and add more to their ranks as the game progresses.

Each turn players will have to choose different locations on the board that suits their strategies from gathering resources, to recuiting wizards & heroes, going into quests, creating potions and spells they can use later, and fighting in the terrible DARK TOWER.

Since this game is euro styled, all of this elements are somewhat abstract, so in order to go into a quest you place a wizard on one of the adventure cards and if you pay the resources needed and have all the requirements for the quest to be successful you win the card and any reward that is given.

Heroes are an important part of the wizard guild as they provide extra abilities to combat and enhance how the resources are gathered. They can go up levels (up to 4) and with each level they grant more to the school they work for. Up to 2 levels can be earn in the usual tavern brawls... but the other 2 must be gain in quests or challenging the DARK TOWER.

Archimago has several elements shared by traditional Eurostyle games that use worker placement but at the same time potions and spells provide and interaction with the other players that if mastered can be of a great assistance to the School, events change game conditions, Characters can appear and add a new location to go to, etc.

The base game comes also with 1 scenario that is made of a set of cards that are mixed with the adventure cards and that when are dealt change the conditions of the game or offer sudden opportunities for the players that have the resources to risk or the desire to count on fate for better possibilities.

The game is modular so it is highly expandable in several directions that will add to the system new possibilities and the feeling of adventure, starting with new scenarios that will make each game feel different, characters that will appear in the different locations to assist the players, events that will happen when creating potions and more sudden apparitions that will contribute greatly with the atmosphere of the world.

The game ends on 1 of 4 conditions:


The adventure cards spots cannot be filled.
2 or 3 lines of potions/spells are depleted.
Sometimes a Scenario Card will end the game when certain conditions are given.
When all the Dark Tower Cards are gone.


In the end Archmage is more than an eurogame, an experience that is worth trying. Each adventure card has been carefully designed so the title leads to the story below. Beyond the abstract elements there is a story going on in the game that those players that are fan of the detail will certainly love.

Spanish description:
El Archimago esta muriendo... un sucesor debe ser encontrado de entre las 4 escuelas de magia, asi que un concurso se realizara. El Rector de la escuela con mayor Prestigio sera el siguiente Archimago.

name: Need for Speed Trading Card Game: Beach Blitz
description:
42 cards deck expansion for Need for Speed
The cards are known, it is not a blind booster.
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game, Racing, Video Game Theme

name: A Match Made in Austen
description:
A Match Made In Austen is a game of storytelling, strategy and serendipity, inspired by the timeless works of Jane Austen. Tell your story, roll the dice, and see if your matches are made in heaven or in hell... or in Austen.

The game contains key male and female characters from the main novels of Jane Austen, namely: Pride and Prejudice, Sense and Sensibility, Emma, Persuasion, Mansfield Park and Northanger Abbey. The goal of the game is to create the best possible romantic matches between them.

Each player has three male cards and three female cards. Each player takes a turn hosting an event (parties, afternoon teas, dinners) and players bring one, or more, pair of male and female characters to the party. During the events, incidents occur, described by the host. Each female character reacts to the event by trying to showcase one of the following virtues: beauty, wit, friendliness, propriety, accomplishments, loyalty, fortune, and independence.

When the event is over, the host chooses the best storyteller among the other players. This player gets an advantage in the next part of the round: the proposal. The players use one male character to propose to one lady present, making their choices according to the virtues listed on the cards.

The game ends when one player has three matches. The player with the most points wins.
mechanics: Acting, Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Role Playing, Storytelling, Voting

name: Miracle: The Battle of Midway
description:
Miracle is Two Generals Games' game on the Battle of Midway.

There are 16 counters (game pieces) representing different kinds of aircraft, ships and even weather for each of the two players. As in the original battle, however, the kinds of units (game pieces) that each player has is different.

Since Miracle does not use dice, it may resemble Chess or perhaps Stratego to you. But both those games are abstract, while this is a strategic simulation of an historical battle from the point of view of the two overall commanders: Admiral Yamamoto for the Imperial Japanese Navy, and U.S. Navy forces sent by Admiral Chester Nimitz. Plus the sides are exactly equal in both Chess and Stratego - here each player has assets and liabilities based on the historical situation. For example, the US has fewer aircraft carriers than the Japanese, but has the unsinkable (but unmovable) Midway Island airbase.

Like both those games previously mentioned - and unlike most wargames - we do not use dice or any other random generator. This means the game emphasizes each players skills in strategy and in tactics to attain his own goals, or at least deny the other player his.

Miracle takes place on a water- and smudge-resistant vinyl map small enough to fit in a notebook. We even supply a ziplock plastic bag for the pieces and a resealable plastic cover for the map, making this a very portable game. The rules are short - two pages - and they're online at all times in case you forget to bring a printed copy. An entire game can be played in 35-45 minutes or less. It's quite possible to play a game during lunch, finish it, and switch sides and play it again.

It's easy to learn the rules and quick to play, but the game plays subtly and mistakes are costly. Take care with your forces! As in the original battle, the slightest mistake can cost you the outcome!
categories: Aviation / Flight, Nautical, World War II

name: Yargo
description:
Yargo is turn-based, strategic battle game for two players. Each player controls a ship with one captain, a pirate crew, and a cheeky monkey. Fight from ship to ship and find out who is the true master of the seas. Basic gameplay structure as follows:


Players start every turn with 4 coins
On your turn, spend your coins on actions from the action menu
Many actions require you to flip a coin to determine outcome
Once you've spent all your coins, it's your opponents turn
The winner is the last crew standing

name: Forces of Warmachine: Cephalyx
description:
For millennia, the cruel and inscrutable Cephalyx have labored at their grisly work. Now the time has come for them to breach the surface, ensnaring the Iron Kingdoms in their nefarious schemes.

Forces of Warmachine: Cephalyx unearths the full power and mystery of the Cephalyx. Enslave the surface dwellers of Caen with:
• The potent warcaster Exulon Thexus and his vicious theme force, Will of Darkness
• Rules for Cephalyx warcasters, monstrosities, and the Cephalyx Mercenary Contract: Puppet Masters
• New units and solos including the Cephalyx Mind Bender & Drudges unit and the Cephalyx Agitator solo
• A painting guide to help you prepare your forces for battle
• All new fiction and background material detailing the history of the cephalyx and their terrifying agenda

Only available as a digital book from Privateer Press.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Cthulhu Deckbuilder
description:
Cards of Cthulhu a deck building game is centered around the Lovecraft genre which Cthulhu is famously known by.

In the game you will compete to build a better deck than the other investigators, defeat Ancient Ones, all the while not going insane.

Cards of Cthulhu is a deckbuilding game where you and up to 4 other players each strive to build the best deck, called your library and score as many victory points in order to win the game. Each player starts the game with the same library, 7 Strengths and 3 Fears. Players shuffle the library and deal themselves 5 cards. Each Strength is worth 1 power. Fears are worth nothing. The opening hand can have from 2 to 5 points of power. The main deck of cards is then dealt 5 cards out to the Storyboard. If any events happen, do what the card says, otherwise, check for card's with surprise effects (which usually add to your insanity). Now the first player takes their turn. They can use their hand of cards to buy items from the storyboard based on their cost (and, in the case of Horrors, the insanity level to banish them). Non-horror cards are placed in that player's graveyard, Horror cards are banished to the banished stack. At the end of the turn, the player draws their five cards again, if the library lacks sufficient cards, shuffle the graveyard back in to the library and complete the rest of the five card draw. The play is passed on to the next player, who then refills the storyboard from the main deck of any cards that were purchased or banished by the prior player. Resolves and event and surprise effects and then their turn starts.

Insanity rules - In the game, it is very important to track just how insane you are! Everyone starts out totally normal - with zero insanity - event, surprise effects and using certain arcane or artifacts will increase or decrease your insanity. If you reach 13 insanity, you have crossed over and succumbed to insanity. At this point, the only way to reduce your insanity is playing cards that reduce your insanity or discarding cards to reduce your insanity by the Victory Point value of the card. You'll need to do this as soon as possible because if your reach 20, you've completely lost your mind and are a vassal for the Ancient Ones (or, in game terms, you just lost and are out of the game).

Ancient Ones - Before the game is started, you separate the Ancient Ones, Azathoth, Hastur and Cthulhu are shuffled and put on the bottom of the stack. Yig is taken out and the rest are shuffled and put on top of the stack. Then Yig is placed face up on the stack. While the Ancient Ones are face up on the stack, they have an effect, called The Haunting - which impacts the game. Yig, for example, cost 8 points to defeat, however, his haunting effect is that, for each two banished Horrors, Yig costs 1 more point to defeat. If three Horrors are banished, Yig would cost 9 points to defeat. When a new ancient one is revealed from the stack, which happens after one has been defeated, they have a one time "awakening" attack - this is an effect that happens immediately when they are turned face up and the attack is against each player. If the player has a defense, they can defend against the attack - if allowed. For example, Ithaqua's Awakening Attack is that each player puts all Allies from their graveyard back in to the story.

Psychic Blast - These cards are put in a stack outside of the main deck or the Ancient One's. They cost three points and can be purchased at anytime during your turn. Sometimes the storyboard will contain cards you don't want or can't buy and you can always buy a Psychic Blast if you would like. When a Psychic Blast is destroyed, it is placed in the destroyed pile. If the stack is empty, no more Psychic blasts can be purchased.

Corruption - These cards are put in a stack outside of the main deck or the Ancient One's. Card effects that say you gain a corruption are from this stack of cards. Corruptions are have a -1 victory point, which, costs you points at the end of the game if they are in your library. When a Corruption is destroyed, it is returned to the corruption stack. If the corruption stack is empty, no more corruptions can be handed out to players.

Investigators - Each player represents an investigator, a Gangster, Law Enforcement, Nun, Priest, Private Investigator, Professor or Psychic. Each investigator has a special ability that allows them to do their special thing during their turns. The Psychic's ability allow that player - at the beginning of their turn, to look at the top two cards of their deck and then put one of those cards in the graveyard. Most of the time, this will help the player select the best of the two cards, possibly discarding a card they would rather not draw, sometimes both cards would work very well, but they still have to discard one. Other abilities affect the cards drawn, power of cards, the storyboard and so on.

name: Der Schatz des Käpt'n Flint
description:
Generations of seafarers have spent their time searching for the fabled treasure, but none have managed to find it. But now Flint's old chart has turned up, on which the hiding places are marked. Multiple pirate ships simultaneously reach the island group in which the treasure chests are hidden. But the restless ghost of Flint is guarding the treasure. Who will be successful and recover the most valuable treasure chest?

The starting player plays with 8 large and 5 small markers, the other one with 8 small and 5 large markers. Players alternate taking turns placing their markers on different spaces, never identically repeating the opponent's move. The game ends when both players have placed all of their 13 markers on the 7 spaces of the island. The 7 spaces are scored one after another. At each space the player with more markers (or in case of equal numbers, more large markers) wins. In case of a tie, no one gets the treasure chests. The player with the most treasure chests wins.

Originally published in spielbox 1991 #4.

name: Terrain: Taxes
description:
With the Terrain: Taxes expansion, players can now place villages on the map, and these villages accrue wealth as more tiles are added to the map.

Additionally, each player has a tax collector who may be sent to a village to tax the coins on it, with each coin being worth 1 victory point at game's end.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Expansion for Base-game, Territory Building

name: Wiener Ringstraße
description: The year 2015 marks the 150th anniversary of the Vienna Ring Road, which circles the Innere Stadt district of Vienna, and Wiener Ringstraße is a tactical dice and collectible card game to celebrate this event and Vienna itself.

name: Calculodingo
description:
CalculoDingo is a goldmine that will accompany your children or students (particularly teachers' aides) in kindergarten and older

The game CalculoDingo offers 12 different rules with the same set of cards. These rules allow to practice counting, additions, subtractions and doubling.
In CalculoDingo you will find the concepts in counting: recognize numbers, compare numbers, insert one number between two others, make sequences of numbers, parity, the decimal system (units and tens).

name: Hellweg westfalicus: Dortmund
description:
Postcard mini-expansion (available for download from the designer's website in German or English).

Dortmund is a new merchandise card.

Every time the owner of the card sells in Dortmund an item of merchandise of the types displayed, he received one extra Thaler (in combination with similar cards accumulating).

name: Quiz Battle
description:
Based on Illusteret Videnskab's mobile game of the same name, players compete against each other while answering questions in six different categories: Sports & leisure, history, entertainment, geography, science & nature and arts & literature.

While doing so, players have an option to get additional advantages by placing their tiles strategically.

The first player to get rid of all tiles is declared the winner.
publishers: Bonniers, Game InVentorS, Illustrerad Vetenskap, Planeto

name: The Battle of Okehazama
description:
Issue game of Wargame Japanese History #25.

Operational level wargame for battle of Okehazama.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Okehazama
Actually, this game is covering Owari　invasion by Imagawa Yoshimoto, and mostly battle may not occur at Okehazama area. The basic game engine use from Jimbo's Nagashino Shitaragahara.

Player control either Oda clan or Imagawa clan. In each turn, player play one of two cards for unit movement or given event.

Winner is determined by victory points or removal of the opponent daimyo(lord). However, Imagawa clan must advance his daimyo to Owari province.

name: Laboratory Mayhem
description:
You are a cunning alchemist, a wielder of one or several of the Six Disciplines. Create fantastical servants, potent spellbombs, transmutations, and nexuses within your laboratory—then use them to reduce your rival's lab to rubble!

Construct a deck of cards representing your laboratory, each card a room that can contain an alchemical recipe, reagents, or workspace: every card in this game can be played in any of three different modes. Combined with our flexible resource system, this means no dead turns. There's always a use for what's in your hand... but finding the optimal use will be necessary if you want to excel at competitive alchemy.

Master Combustion, Metallurgy, Reanimation, Astrology, Naturalism, Toxicology, or ANY combination thereof, and use their power to attack or otherwise damage your opponent's lab. Your goal? Empty their deck, destroying every room in their laboratory. Alternate turns gathering reagents, playing recipes, and attacking with your servants.

Laboratory Mayhem is a game of complex strategy. Experienced players are constantly discovering new strategies and tactics. For new players, there are entry-level duel decks designed to let you jump in immediately and learn as you go. This game is designed for 2 players to go head to head but is playable with any number, and our team and fans are always thinking up new formats. Lab Mayhem can be bought in sets, so, while you can trade with other players, you can also get all the cards you want up front for a reasonable price.

name: The Prince: The Struggle of House Borgia – Condottiere
description: 4 Condottiere (Power 4, Mercenary Fee: 5) cards. Each of the 4 is in a different language. One of the appropriate language should be added to the deck.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Political, Renaissance

name: Apicultura
description:
Apicultura is a card drafting, resource conversion game about breeding bees, harvesting honey and selling it to maximize your profit.

The player at the end of the game who has collected the most income is the winner.

In Apicultura, each player has a player board representing their own individual honey farm and a hand of identical action cards.

At the start of the game the players begin with 2 lowly Level A hives (these can be upgraded later).

Every turn the Action Cards are drafted which allow players to Breed Bees (add a new hive in a space where there are already 2 hives), Plant Fields (increasing the maximum number of hives permitted), Produce Honey ("spending" hives for the round to generate honey), Upgrade Hives which increases the quality (and value) of the honey produced and as well as Sell Honey (either to exclusive honey boutiques or direct to the public at a reduced rate) depending on the demand for their particular product. The honey can also be marketed or refined which can increases its value, or simply opt to generate a small amount of income.

name: コクーン・ワールド　ザ・ボードゲーム (Cocoon World: The Board Game)
description:
コクーン・ワールド　ザ・ボードゲーム (Cocoon World: The Board Game) is a racing game in which the players construct the board while they play. On a turn, a player rolls one or more dice in the dice tower, move their pawn, then places a tile on the game board that, for example, moves their pawn again forward or backward a specified number of spaces or rewarded them experience points (EPs).

In general, the player who has the most EPs wins, but the game includes five scenarios that change the rules and goals somewhat.

name: Schäferstündchen: Der Holzfäller
description:
Promo Role

From the card:

Bewegung 3
Kampf 4

Du kannst nur eine Vergabekarte erhalten.

Movement 3
Fight 4

You can only receive one Allocation Card.
categories: Animals, Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Humor, Racing

name: Alician Draughts
description:
The rules of Alician Draughts were first described in the book "Les Jeux de dames non orthodoxes et autres jeux à pions" in 1956.

The standard game of International Draughts is played using two boards, A and B. The normal array is on board A; board B starts empty.

In turn, each player makes a single move on either board following these three rules:

1. A move must be legal on the board where it is played.
2. A piece can only move or capture if the corresponding destination square on the other board is vacant.
3. After moving, the piece is transfered to the corresponding square on the other board.

The original board (not the "mirror board") decides the game:

Whenever a player has no piece left on the original board, he loses even within a move. A move consists of up to three stages: Movement (which can be a jump in case of a capture), Transfer of the moved piece to the other board, Removal of any captured pieces. That is, if at any stage a player had no pieces left on the original board, he lost the game.

In practice, it is possible to play Alician Draughts on a single board, if the checkers have a piece of felt glued to their bottom. When a piece (men or king) is transferred to the "mirror board", it is just turned upside down.

Despite many similarities Alician Draughts is in fact a very different game. While in International Draughts more than 50% of all tournament games today end in a draw, in Alician Draughts a draw is impossible.

name: Gelegenheit macht Diebe
description: The annual watch and jewelery fair has opened its doors. On countless stalls outrageously expensive watches, precious gems and valuable jewelery are presented. A lot of money is involved. As you can already come into temptation. But a foray really worth? How good are your own maps? And what have before the others present? Because in addition to sophisticated thieves are also police officers, insurance agents and private spot. Given the many uninvolved visitors who do not think of a theft in a dream. But all want to score! Winning can in this turmoil just who succeeds at each of the six days of the fair to take on a new role and to keep the competition at bay. Billing is at the very end!

name: Scene It? Turner Classic Movies Game Pack
description: Expansion pack includes a Scene It' DVD and 100 trivia cards. The patented Optreve technology on the Scene It' DVD lets you play without seeing the same questions repeatedly. Requires original Scene It' board game (sold separately), TV and DVD player. For two or more players.
categories: Electronic, Expansion for Base-game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Trivia

name: Colt Express: Indians & Cavalry
description: A stand alone cooperative version of Colt Express.

name: Stones of Fate: Bonus Pack 1
description: A pack of 12 bonus cards for use with Stones of Fate. These cards were reached in the Stones of Fate Kickstarter project.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Memory, Mythology, Renaissance
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Auction/Bidding, Memory, Pattern Recognition, Set Collection

name: ManaSurge: Elementals
description: This mini-expansion introduces the Elementals that can change the suit of a card you play on your turn giving you more control on when to score!
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Number

name: Star
description:
Star is a two-player abstract strategy game designed by Ea Ea as the third out of four games by him extending or generalizing Hex. The four games in publication order: The Game of Y, Poly-Y, Star, and *Star. See further details of the developmental history at the designer's homepage.

The game board for Star is a hexagon with uneven side lengths made up of hexagonal spaces (e.g. alternating edge length of 6 and 7 hexes). On the board, the playing area is surrounded by a ring of "partial edge hexagons" used for final scoring. The two players (black and white) takes turns to place one stone (in their color) on any un-occupied hex space in the playing area. The goal of the game is to create "stars" - groups of connected stones belonging to one player that touches at least three partial edge hexagons. Each star has a score of the number of partial edge hexagons it touches minus two. The final score of a player is the sum of points for all the stars of that players color. The player with the highest score wins. The sum of the two players score is constant for any particular board.

From Wikipedia:
Star is a two-player abstract strategy board game developed by Craige Schensted (now Ea Ea). It was first published in 1983 in Games magazine. It is a connection game, related to games such as Hex, Y, Havannah, and TwixT. Unlike these games, however, the result is based on a player having a higher final score rather than achieving a specific goal. He has since developed a slightly more complicated version called *Star with better balance between edge and center moves, writing "*Star is what those other games wanted to be."

name: Gothic Invasion: Cards Expansion 1
description:
This official expansion adds 8 new cards to Gothic Invasion. These can be added without problems to the original cards.

They are:

3 new objectives cards
2 new Roman action cards
2 new Gothic action cards
1 new annual event card
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Secret Unit Deployment, Variable Player Powers

name: Birds of a Feather: Undomesticated Owl Bear Promo
description:
Promo card from 2016 Table Top Day.

The Undomesticated Owl Bear has an appetite for eggs, but is easily confused. Try to spot this mysterious creature!

Setup: Place this card to the side. Right now, no one controls the Owl Bear.

Each Round: After revealing cards, count the egg cards played this round. If zero or two or more players played an egg card, the Owl Bear is confused and doesn't move.
If one player played an egg card, and she didn't already control the Owl Bear, she gains control of it! She can immediately mark one uncommon spot from any habitat. Place this card in front of her.
categories: Animals, Card Game, Educational, Expansion for Base-game
mechanics: Hand Management, Set Collection, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Flint and Feather
description:
From the publisher:

Flint and Feather is a 28mm, individual figure, tabletop skirmish game system of tribal warfare between the First Nations of the Great Lakes region in the legendary Pre-Contact era. Unleash your Great Warrior and assemble your Warband to raid and plunder your opponent and grow your Orenda.

Attack and Defense Card System: This unique combat system gives you the ability to choose the attack or defense maneuver of your key characters providing a critical decision point in the game during each and every melee you may fight.

Medicine Roll Initiative System: This creative initiative system allows interesting aspects of the Native American Indian mythology to be added into the game play and provides the game with more of a feel for the Legendary Pre-Contact period.

Orenda: This word is the Iroquoian name for the spiritual power inherent in people, animals and the environment. The rich Iroquoian mythology introduces aspects that allow us to creatively add magic, spells and spirit creatures to the game. Of course the wargame purist does not have to add these rules to the game if your inclination is for standard combat.
categories: American Indian Wars, Book, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Simulation

name: Soccer City: Legends of Soccer City
description:
Legends of Soccer City takes the game to the next level.

Each card is a Legendary Player. Each character has his own personality, career and unique skills.

Those features are special skills, values for each player and a specific role in the team.

It is simple mechanics. The values and special skills of each character will be added to the player with the specific number on the pitch.

There are 3 different characters for each number. Every match, each Mister will choose his own team, so every match will be different.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Hand Management, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Dumpster Brawl!: Ernie Promo Card
description:
A promo card handed out at BGG.CON 2015.

Text of card:

Play Ernie at any time to done of the following:
1) Randomly draw up to two (2) cards from any player's hand.
2) Place up to (2) cards into another player's hand.
3) Randomly draw one card from any player's hand and place one card into their hand.
This CAN be played as a player is declaring victory to stop them.
Discard this card after it is played.
categories: Animals, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Party Game
