King’s Gambit is a hand held 18-card solo game. The goal of King’s Gambit is simple: 1) defeat all four Assassins in the forest, OR 2) find the King (who is lost in the forest), and escort him safely through the forest back to the Castle. To do that, you must outwit the Assassins who are trying to kill the King. The Assassins can also wound you! The King’s guards (who are also lost in the forest) can protect the King and you as well...if you can find them. The King also has Allies who can help you in your noble quest, but the King also has Enemies who will hinder your quest. Don’t lose your way, or you too might get lost in the ever changing forest!

—description from the designer

name: Warhammer Age of Sigmar: Death Battletome – Flesh-Eater Courts
description:
Battletome: Flesh-Eater Courts is the  guide to fielding a Flesh-Eater army for Age of Sigmar.

This book contains a miniatures showcase illustrating colour schemes and painting advice, plus examples of painted models. It also features rules for fielding your Flesh-Eater army in games of Age of Sigmar.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Tempus Quest: Episode 3 – Decision at Degna
description:
An honest days work is well and good, but nothing pays quite like crime, and between the usual backbone of smugglers and petty crooks, and the destabilizing presence of the liberation at Degna Station, there is more than enough work here to pay for at least a metajumps worth of fuel.

Games in the Tempus series work similarly to roll and write games where players roll dice and use the results to fill in a sheet. In the Tempus System, instead of using dice, players will use the date and time to randomize setup and available actions.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Grid Movement, Network and Route Building, Set Collection, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: ORC
description:
2 Player game similar to The Duke, but with hidden movement of pieces.

Players play a piece one at a time by their movement rules and try to win by 1 of 3 conditions:


Get your yellow king piece to the other side
Take opponents yellow king piece
Your opponent takes your blue jester piece
publishers: Little Future (リトルフューチャー), Swan Panasia Co., Ltd.

name: Black Stories: Nele Neuhaus Edition
description:
Black Stories has been the riddle game series with bestsellers for over 13 years. Nele Neuhaus is Germany's most successful crime author: Over 10 million books have been sold!
She created 50 brand new hair-raising, brilliant black stories.

Black Stories are fiddly, morbid and mysterious riddles for teenagers and adults. The players try to reconstruct the crime by asking, guessing and fiddling about. A spooky card game just right for any party.
categories: Book, Card Game, Deduction, Humor, Murder/Mystery, Party Game

name: Jó étvágyat, kuflik!
description:
A collection of three more or less original chidren's games (using tiles, pawns and tokens) in one box, based on the theme of a popular Hungarian cartoon and literature series.

The first game is more or less like Little Orchard - a 'bear lizard' is approaching the berry bush and you need to find the berries on face-down tiles before it reaches the bush (when you turn up a tile with a bear lizard the bear lizard moves one step toward the bush).

The second game is a roll and move with two dice and a few different options on what to do with a single roll (move according to one of the dice or the sum of them, forward or backwards) : here you are collecting these berry tokens along the way (moving forward and backwards) while the bear lizard is trying to eat the berries you have already collected (moving back and forth along the path, taking as many steps as the higher die face shows).

In the third game players play cooperatively. You try to collect berries and transport them to the middle on a square grid of tiles while the bear lizard keeps eating the berries from the nearest bushes - or players.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Memory, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: The Juno Beach Landings
description:
Part of Against the Odds Magazine's Pocket Battle Games series, this is the fourth of their "Five For Fighting" series of linked games covering the D-Day invasion.

LPS Pocket Battle Game #24

name: Schwerpunkt: Volume 21
description: 12 ASL scenarios for the Advanced Squad Leader system.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Modular Board, Secret Unit Deployment

name: Tóu-shì
description:
骰是

'Tóushì - the Dicegrid puzzle game'

Overview
The goal of the game is to fill in as many squares on the grid as possible, completed rows and columns will give bonus points when scoring.

During play, you roll dice to move around the grid and mark off squares. Every round but the first is much the same. You roll a die and use it to solve the grid puzzle and mark off two numbers from the lists of numbers, one for the type of die you use for the roll and one for the type of die you choose to mark on the board. If all numbers of a die type are used, you could no longer choose to roll this type of die or write that die type to the grid.

The die roll will be used both as the limit of movement and the number to cross off. You do not have to write the same die type on the grid as you roll, but the number used, must be within the range of the die type. Remember that there may not be two of the same die type written into any row or column.

There are three bonus actions to use during the game (the star symbols on the gameboard). Be aware that using them all will end the game, regardless of whether or not there are squares left to fill in. Resolve any movements before ending the game, after the last bonus action is used.

The first round will be different.

First round
Chose a number from any list of numbers, mark this off and place your first mark on the board in any square on the grid. Write either a number, symbol or letters to remember what die type you chose. At the sides of the grid, there is die type symbols for all columns and rows, to help guide you, you could mark these off as well. This marked square is your starting position. The following rounds movements must start from the position of the previous round. You may not end a movement in a previously marked square.

Any following round
Start the round by choosing one die of any type.

Mark off a number of own choice from the list of numbers the same die type as the die type you use.

Roll the die, and use this number shown to move, and to mark off a number from any list of numbers (associated with a die type), this is the die type you mark to the board. It has not to be the same as the die type you rolled.

Rolling a one
If you roll the number one with any die, you either chose to reroll or use one bonus action. Unused bonus actions are worth four points at the end of the game.

The Bonus action
If you use a bonus action after a roll of one. Cross out one of your three bonus markers and mark one square anywhere on the grid with a die type of your own choice. This will be your starting position next round. Remember to cross out one number of that die type as well.

The bonus action could also be used as a reroll of any die roll during play. If you use the last bonus action for a reroll, resolve the roll and movements, mark a square and off number if possible before ending the game.

Movement
You move by subtracting from your die roll. For each square you move, reduce the die roll with one. You could not go down to zero or below.

You may not move diagonally. You may move over and past marked squares as long as you do not end movement on a marked square.

You do not have to move in a straight line, you may do as many turns as you like, as long as you do not cross a square twice or move diagonally.

Marking a square
The square you end your movement in is marked with letters (T+number) or the die type symbol of the chosen die, from which number list you also mark off a number. Remember that there may not be two of the same die type in any row or column.

Example
If you roll a four and move two steps, you now have the number two to mark off from a die list of numbers (and remember to mark this die type in the square you ended up in). You may choose any die type as long as this number is within its number range and is available to mark off in the list of numbers of that die type.

Game ends
The game ends when either one of these conditions is fulfilled.

The player had used the last (of three) bonus actions.

Is unable to move to an empty square (due to the result of the die roll and/or available numbers to cross out).

All squares are filled.

Scoring
Each filled square equals to one point. (up to 36 points)

Each filled column equals to three points. (up to 18 points)

Each filled row equals to three points. (up to 18 points)

Each saved (unused) bonus action equals to four points. (up to 12 points)

The Grid
The dice icons next to the grid is for ease of gameplay, just to keep track of dice type per column and row

—description from the designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Affectionate: Cats and Cuddles – It's Treat Time!
description:
The It's Treat Time expansion adds some more components to the bag of Affectionate: Cats and Cuddles: 1 Rulebook, 5 Cat Mats, 5 Cat pawns, and 1 Reference Mat.

It's Treat Time;; provides two new ways to play Affectionate: an Advanced version introducing a new mechanic - dice drafting (choosing dice from a common pool in turn order) and the "It's Treat Time" Expansion which adds the mechanic of worker placement - using a pawn to choose from a limited number of actions.

With It's Treat Time, Affectionate is not only a light, fun game, but a way to introduce game mechanics and concepts to younger or less experienced players.

Even with all of these additions, Affectionate: Cats and Cuddles & It's Treat Time Expansion is a light, silly game about being the sweetest cat in the house and its expansions brings new ways to play this simple, sweet game.

—description from the publisher

name: The Lion of Khartoum: Gordon's Last Stand – Game Supplement
description:
Includes twelve [12] additional Event cards, two [2] new rules, and one [1] additional scenario.

Event Cards:
Card No. 21 A small group of Ansars successfully infiltrates the
City, causing mayhem
Card No. 22 There is growing tension between Sudanese and
Egyptian troops
Card No. 23 Your heavy Guns fire back at enemy artillery
Card No. 24 You refuse the Mahdi"s offer to surrender
Card No. 25 Nothing special happens. For now.
Card No. 26 Khartoum's citizens pressure you for results
Card No. 27 Undisciplined Bashi bazouks cause trouble in the
City.
Card No. 28 You can set up a small garrison on Tuti Island to
protect Fort Omdurman
Card No. 29 You may opt to raid enemy supply lines.
Card No. 30 Issue siege bank notes to prop up the City's
economy.
Card No. 31 The Shaigiya Tribe proposes to join your cause.
Card No. 32 Frank Power, The Times of London correspondent,
helps morale.

New Rules:
6.7.1 Reserves
7.2.1 Overrun

New Scenario: The Beginning of the End [it uses five of the new Event Cards]

The new Event cards have been printed are quite differently. As a result, included in the Game Supplement are 20 Event Cards and 12 Banner Cards to replace the cards from the base game.

Components:
Twelve [12] New Event Cards
One [1], four page, rules booklet
Twenty [20] replacement Event Cards
Twelve [12] replacement Banner Cards
9x12 ziplock

All game components fit in the base game box.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Post-Napoleonic, Print & Play, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Simulation

name: Straight 4
description:
Easy to learn, deceptively strategic. Simply try to get your four pieces in a row before your opponent. Designed to be very small and portable, this is the perfect game when on the road.

Game play is very straightforward. Each player takes turns placing a piece on board in an attempt to have their 4 pieces in a straight line. If, after initial placement no one is winning, then each player takes turn moving their pieces along any lines. This creates quite a bit of strategy as each player must strike a balance between trying to get their 4 in a row, or stopping their opponent from doing so.

Quick and easy to setup and play, the game is suitable for anyone ages 7 or older. It is a pure strategy game like chess, meaning that there is no chance involved in the game.
mechanics: Pattern Recognition, Point to Point Movement

name: Pride of Lions (Second Edition)
description:
This 122 page ruleset seeks to provide a fast and fun game of fantasy mass combat. It is the designer’s belief that the best games result from a combination of simple rules mechanics and the opportunity for the players to make many decisions.

In Pride of Lions the role of each player is that of the commanding general of the army or warlord of the horde. Magic, and the courage and skills of individual heroes, can affect the game, but the outcome of the battle will depend mainly on the clash of large units of common fighters operating under the general’s orders.

Each turn begins with players issuing orders to eligible units by laying inverted movement chits behind each unit. After a magic phase, which can result in a unit’s orders being changed involuntarily or randomly, all orders are revealed and movement is conducted simultaneously by all sides but in a strict sequence, with the most aggressive movement (charges) coming first and skirmishers going last. Both melee combat and missile fire are conducted through opposed die rolls, using dice of various sizes from D4s to D24’s, with the difference between the die rolls determining the outcome. Factors such as terrain, magic, special weapons and tactics, and leadership and heroism by characters all affect the game either through the movement chits or the die rolls.

WHY A SECOND EDITION? HOW IS THIS ONE DIFFERENT? We have a LOT more experience of gaming with these rules now, and 2nd edition reflects lessons learned. There are numerous tweaks, as well as places where a longer explanation seemed necessary for clarity. There are lots of photos, partly to show off our miniatures but also as examples of play. And there are some substantial changes:


The point system is completely revised, with much greater detail, and applies now to characters as well as to units.
Dwarven rune magic is much more detailed.
Godfearers’ “magic” – prayer and spiritual gifts – is also far more detailed and extensive.
Spirits are developed further.
There are more and longer generic army lists and spell lists.
And the movement sequence of air units is better.


—description from the designer
categories: Ancient, Dice, Fantasy, Fighting, Medieval, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Pecha Libre
description:
Pecha Libre is a party game by the makers of Cat and Chocolate (Gentosha). Players pit ridiculous characters against each other in battle using best persuasion skills to convince their friends that they have the superior fighter. It’s simple but can be a lot of fun with a good group of friends.

—descrpiption from the publisher

name: Kung Fu Fighting (2019 reboot)
description:
Kung Fu Fighting is a fast, hilarious, action-packed card game for 2-6 players in which you are a combatant in a free-for-all martial arts movie fight scene. Unleash a Flying, Flipping, Spinning Kick on your opponents, but be careful to hang onto a Block or two for when they try to do the same to you!

As SlugFest's first published game, Kung Fu Fighting has always held a special place in our hearts and the hearts of our longtime fans. This exciting card game hit a really good sweet spot as a quick and light game that still had some interesting choices and lots of silly, over-the-top cinematic Kung Fu moments.

So after it was out of print we tried to Kickstart a totally new edition: fancy art, overhauled mechanics, higher production value, etc. Response was overwhelmingly meh.

Since that failed project, we've thought a lot about this game, and we still get occasional requests for reprints. After the success of our low-key print-on-demand version of En Garde Reforged, we decided we should do the same thing for Kung Fu Fighting.

We are very much using the KISS principle for this project: Keep It Simple, SlugFest! Rather than redoing everything (art, mechanics, etc.), we are simply creating a lightly-updated set of cards with the original art and mechanics and sending that off to our friends at DriveThruCards for printing.

—description from the publisher

name: At Villers Cottérêts: Mons 1914
description:
At Villers Cottérêts: Mons 1914 is a tactical, battalion scale game on the rearguard action during the battle of Mons where a massively outnumbered BEF brigade held up 2 German divisions for an afternoon until another friendly force arrived and was able to cover their retreat. The battle itself is embelematic of the whole Mons campaign in itself where the BEF consistently found themselves outnumbered in every engagement, though managing miraculous tactical victories strung together into a strategic victory at the outset of the war.

The mechanics put a focus on command and control, only allowing forces in command with one another to cooperate or concentrate fire. Each SP will be approximately 100-250 rifles. Turns are 30 minutes lasting from 0630 to 1400.

This game will be part of the 2140 series, so it will include the standard map, 140 counters, rules and possibly some player aids and dice.

WEIGHT: 8-9/10

SOLITAIRE: 7/10

—description from the publisher

name: Apocrypha Adventure Card Game: Allusion Promo Card
description: Promo Card given by Lone Shark Games when The Flesh Expansion is purchased from their online store. This promo is a mind gift which allows your saint to discard to gain an additional mind die. If during the turn of the saint to your left or right is confronting while wearing something that is not clothing, you may recycle this card and give the active saint one fragment for them to slot in their halo.
categories: Adventure, Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Horror
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Role Playing, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Variable Player Powers

name: Thunder Visitors
description:
"Even though you don't see us, we are four factions soaring through the atmosphere searching for perfect thunders to record. In this game you're one of us! Your goal is to create thunder and record that beautiful sound of ephemeral energy flowing to planet earth"

Thunder Visitors is a game that can be printed on a single sheet (both a low and a full ink version are available). It can be played solo or with two or three players.

Your goal is to manage the cards in your hand and manipulate your die on the grid so you can create thunder and score points while recording it.

Players select cards and compare cards simultaneously to determine which actions they can play. By combining 4 different elements depicted on their cards, they create thunder which they can record.

Thunder Visitors combines a puzzle (pattern building) with simultaneous action selection (bidding for actions and playing order), that also works well when played solo.

—description from the designer
categories: Abstract Strategy, Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Dice, Print & Play
mechanics: Action Queue, Area Movement, Betting and Bluffing, Grid Movement, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Point to Point Movement, Simultaneous Action Selection, Tile Placement

name: Jibbergiggle
description:
Jibbergiggle is a party game that takes everyday scenarios and challenges you to act them out using only ridiculous nonsense words and your own expressive face.

Can you calm down a bear using only the words 'wimmy wozzle' or propose to your partner by saying 'patootie'? Master the art of spouting nonsense in silly noises, as others attempt to guess what exactly it is you're trying to do!

—description from the publisher

name: The Pact
description:
This is a group of scenarios covering hypothetical modern tactical conflicts in Central Europe (focusing on the Warsaw Treaty Organization) using FIREPOWER. It starts with an in-depth review of the history of the conflict and related forces, including tactics, unit composition and equipment lists and then provides the following scenarios:

Along the Weser
Bavarian Ambush
Object Frankfurt
Nuclear Battlefield
The Edge of Hamburg
The French Strike Back

This expansion was first published as an article in The General, Vol. 24, No. 1 (1987).

—user summary
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Modern Warfare, Wargame
mechanics: Chit-Pull System, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Line of Sight, Movement Points, Simulation

name: Tactile Touch!
description:
Robin lives on a beautiful farm that is a lively place each and every day. Today, the animal babies are playing hide & seek, and Robin must search for them. Four different games in which children learn to recognize and allocate the animals by touching and feeling. Children can also play with the materials creatively, delving into countless role games springing up around life on the farm.

An entertaining touch & find game for 1 to 3 children ages 2 and older.

—description from the publisher

name: 3rd Fleet: Fleet Architecture
description:
From the Expansion:

"One of 3rd FLEET's limitations as a game is a shortage of scenarios. Other tactical/operational wargames overcome such a shortcoming by offering a system for designing your own(DYO) scenarios. But, for that one needs some manner in which to compare the units of the game. The following is an approximate valuation for each unit in 3rd FLEET based upon relative "combat power", allowing players to customize their own fleets for additional scenarios.

These "purchase points" are given per-unit; the number in parentheses is the number of such counters provided in the game's countermix. If nuclear weapons are to be used, pay the
cost to the right of the slash mark. Players may also purchase damaged units at half-cost. Each player may purchase mines for placement before the start of the match for five points each.

Before the game, the opposing players should agree upon the purchase level for each side, with each side getting the same number of points to work with. Roughly speaking, use 400-1000 points per side for a low-complexity scenario; 1000-3000 points for a scenario of medium length/complexity; and 4000+ points for an advanced scenario. A detailed breakdown of the point values of existing scenarios is provided for comparison purposes in the first sidebar."

It also provides for the following four new scenarios, complete with Special Rules, Game Length, Victory Conditions, and detailed Deployment:

Cuba Libre!
Melee in the Caribbean
Assault on Jamaica
Red SeaLion

This expansion was first published as an article in The General, Vol. 27, No. 2 (1991).

name: 2nd Fleet: War Under the Midnight Sun
description:
The one feature that contributes most to 2nd FLEET's attractiveness as a game of strategy is its excellent playability. The sub-systems work very well together, and play flows smoothly even in the Advanced Game. The optional Logistics rules are the worst impediment to playability, but even these manifest themselves only at the end of every third turn; experienced, well-organized players can cope with these
readily enough.

As with all "modem" wargames dealing with hypothetical conflict, 2nd FLEET shares the problem that it must amount to an "educated guess". There is no history against which its accuracy can be closely measured (the recent Gulf War notwithstanding). This situation is especially acute for naval games, as there has yet to be a conflict encompassing all the elements embraced by the FLEET series. For example, although guided missiles, airpower, submarines and surface vessels all took part in the Falklands War, there was no simultaneous use of all four elements of naval power in a coordinated manner by both sides in any single engagement. If 2nd FLEET must be an educated guess, however, then it is a very educated one. Another expert might argue with Joe Balkoski's systemic forecast of modem naval warfare, but until the awful day that the real world provides a real standard to judge by, 2nd FLEET's accuracy stands to be as good as that of any other game on the subject.

There are some areas in which players can afford to experiment with the rules, however. One lies in force deployment. The Readiness Level selected for the Advanced Game scenarios and subsequent die rolls for reinforcement can accelerate or decelerate the arrival of units, but the general pattern of disposition remains the same. As warships and air units can move faster than the political events leading to a superpower conflict, this pattern should not be viewed as rigidly unalterable.

—description from the publisher

The expansion provides variants focusing on deployment options for NATO and the Soviet Union.

—user summary
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Modern Warfare, Nautical, Wargame

name: Poo Poo Fighting
description:
Poo Poo Fighting consists of 112 cards printed on poker-sized cards, plus an instruction booklet in Italian and English languages. Poo Poo Fighting means tons of poo poo and laughs!

It's an exhilarant and strategic card game where players take turns drawing cards and attacking other players with as much kgs of Poo Poo as possible.

The Scope of the game is collecting fewer Poo Poo Cards than other players!

Poo Poo Fighting is absolutely easy to learn and to play, suitable for people of all ages and recommended for family, children and good friends.

The deck is made up of amazing attack cards that force your opponent to take Kgs and Kgs of “Poo Poo Cards”. Also you can defend yourself against attacks or discharge some Poo Poo using the appropriate special cards.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Humor, Party Game
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Player Elimination

name: Red Chicken Rising
description:
Red Chicken Rising is a game about tactical spaceship combat in the Generic Legions universe. This game reflects the battle scenes of sci fi movies and TV shows. This is the science fiction of the Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, of Red Dwarf, of Mystery Science Theater 3000, of Futurama, and of Galaxy Quest.

Red Chicken Rising is intended for use in battles involving anywhere up to a hundred ships on each side, or more. Therefore, the scope is on fleet actions, not the details of any particular ship. The mechanisms of movement and combat reflect this scope.

This game is built around the Generic Legions universe. The GL background may be left out and the game used as a generic sci fi spaceship system, or you can tack on the sci fi background of your choice.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Ghoullotine
description:
Ghoullotine is a fast and ghoulish card game with some themes inspired by the likes of Blackjack.

Each player has a hand of 3 cards that they must use to the best of their ability. During a player’s turn, they will play 1 card from their hand, it’s number is added to the total. Then, if the total is above “13”, then that player is removed from the game. If the total isn’t higher than “13”, then the effect of the card activates. Such effects may be the “Witch’s” ability to swap hands with another player or the “Ghoul’s” ability to skip a player’s next turn.

This game has a surprising amount of tricks and tactics to employ, that’ll keep you addicted to this treat of a game.

—description from the designer
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Deduction, Fantasy, Party Game
mechanics: Hand Management, Push Your Luck, Take That

name: Kipicot
description:
A GAME OF STRATEGY
OBJECT: earn as many sea urchin tokens as possible.
To be able to catch sea urchins without pricking your fingers, you have to reposition them into very precise squares. Strategically place the pieces and anticipate opponents’ moves to win points!

+++ An exciting, dynamic game of strategy!

—description from the publisher

name: Hideyoshi's Domination of Japan
description:
This game is played by two players, Hideyoshi player and anti-Hideyoshi player. Hideyoshi player is disadvantaged in the battle field but by using various powerful event cards, he will break down the powerful anti-Hideyoshi camp by plot.
Various event cards color the game.
The game begins with the defeat of Akechi Mitsuhide, and initially only a few former Oda Daimyos are in play. As the game progresses, influential Daimyo from various places will participate and the battlefield will gradually expand throughout Japan.

Contents

198 counters
1 map
32 cards (2 card sheets)

name: Hodów 1694
description:
"Hodów 1694" is a wargame simulation of the Battle of Hodów between the Kingdom of Poland and Crimean Khanate forces, fought in June 1694 in the Ruthenian Voivodeship of the Crown of the Kingdom of Poland, near the village of Hodów (now in Zboriv Raion, Ternopil Oblast, Ukraine).

Often it is called "The Polish Thermopylae", like the Battle of Wizna, fought in 1939 between Polish and Germans in the first days of the Second World War, which is the subject of a second wargame published in that same 42 issue of the Polish wargaming magazine "Taktyka i Strategia".

name: Family Plot 2
description:
Family Plot 2 is a sequel to the original, but even WORSER. It has the same play dynamics with all new cards including new Modifiers, Actions, etc. It also comes in a BIG ASS BOX with Modifier Tokens, Game Mat and Card Separators!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Hand Management, Push Your Luck, Take That

name: Le jeu questionnaire RPM: L'univers de l'automobile
description:
RPM is a trivia game where you answer question from one of 5 categories: Car race, Who am I (car parts), Jet Set (famous cars and people), Technology and History.

The game progresses on a board where each square indicates one or two question category from which you may choose. You move on the board using die. There are also some bonuses found on the board to help you get to the end faster than your opponents.

—user summary

name: Super Nova Smash!
description:
Super Nova Smash! is a fast-paced phone + card party game for 2-8 players about racing through the blast of a supernova. The goal is to get rid of your cards before your friends — and do as much damage as you can while you go.

The deck consists of 96 cards, numbered 0-5. You can play one card higher or lower than the card on top of a play pile, including your on your own pile, and those numbers wrap, so you can play a 5 on a 0 and vice versa. The "0" card is special, though, in that it counts as damage (negative points), counted at the end of the round, so it's best to try to play them on other people's piles while defensively keeping your pile as far from 0 as you can.

The app is there to tell you when to play, give you random challenges, and generally make your life a panic-inducing nightmare (in a fun way!). The app will randomly (but evenly) assign turn order and occasionally force all players to compete in quick, frantic mini-games on the device — often when they least expect it.

The first person to get rid of all their cards and tap the button in the middle of their screen gets the most Space Points, with fewer points being given to each player as they finish. Once all players are done, they are asked to count their damage (cards marked "0"), and then the app will calculate their scores for the round.

Rounds typically last about 3-6 minutes, and the player with the most Space Points at the end of 10 rounds wins!

—description from the designer
categories: Action / Dexterity, Card Game, Party Game, Racing, Video Game Theme
mechanics: End Game Bonuses, Events, Interrupts, Race, Real-Time, Simultaneous Action Selection, Speed Matching, Take That, Track Movement, Turn Order: Random

name: すべてが登米になる (Subete ga Tome ni Naru)
description:
すべてが登米になる (Subete ga Tome ni Naru, "Everything Will Become Tome") is an area control game where you are a surveyor deciding how to redistrict the city of Tome in Miyagi Prefecture. The area control aspect is fairly traditional with two major twists: areas will merge as you play, and there are unique rules for hand management.

Every player starts the game with the same hand of nine cards, one for each district in Tome, but the cards are shuffled and can't be reordered after picking them up. Each round you pick two of the first three cards in your hand and use one to determine where you place cubes and the other to determine how many cubes you place. Cards that let you place two cubes correspond to more central and thus valuable districts, so you have to choose between good placement or more cubes.

After a district is filled with cubes accounting takes place, and typically after each accounting a "friendship token" will be placed between two districts, connecting them. After that filling individual districts still triggers accounting, but during accounting cubes in directly connected friendly districts are counted the same as cubes in the district itself. In the extreme case you could even take first place in a district you have no cubes in if you've packed a friendly neighbor.

—user summary

name: Mein Lotta-Leben: Alles voller Kaninchen
description:
Lotta and her friends have to catch Cheyenne's rabbits which escaped. The top of the variable game board shows five characters from the book series, the bottom shows five locations. In between there is a labyrinth consisting of four stripes with paths on them.
One player rolls a dice, determining from which of the characters a rabbit escaped. All players follow the path of the rabbit and try to determine which location it is hiding in. Rabbits always turn when they have the chance, and if the stripe shows two rabbit holes, they change from one to the other. When a player thinks they know where the rabbit is, they grab the corresponding location tile first. If successful, they get to keep one of the stripes which is then replaced by another. Tiles that have been used are returned face down, so a memory aspect is added. When all stripes have been dealt out, the player with most stripes wins.

name: Aeronautica Imperialis: Wings of Vengeance – Rudok Redz Promo Card
description: This promo card was included in the December 2019 issue of White Dwarf Magazine along with promos for 3 other games. It is has the ability "Grot Bomb Ace."
categories: Aviation / Flight, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: Blood Bowl (2016 edition): Ogre Team Booster
description:
You might not imagine Ogre culture to be especially egalitarian, but both male and female Ogres play Blood Bowl with equal gusto in the Ogre Kingdoms. Ogre women have a similar build and temperament to Ogre men, including that crucial aptitude for grievous violence.

If you're looking to field the maximum number of Ogres on your team, these two distinctive sculpts will keep them from looking the same. They mix and match perfectly with the Fire Mountain Gut Busters, plus you get an extra Gnoblar to kick around!

This 16-piece resin kit builds two Ogre players and one Gnoblar. They’re supplied with 1x 25mm bases and 2x 32mm bases.

Rules for using these models in your games of Blood Bowl can be found in issue 8 of Spike! Journal.

—description from the publisher
categories: Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Sports
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: Samourai
description:
Samourai is a simple miniature skimish ruleset in Medieval Japan.

It is based on DBA to be played with 15mm minis. 25mm can be used too.

Sequence of play:
1st player phase:

Move active player units
Shooting of units not in contact
Mêlée of units in contact


then 2nd player go through same sequence

name: ATS Dien Bien Phu 2016
description:
Dien Bien Phu, FRENCH INDOCHINA, 28 March 1954: By March 27th, General DeCastries faced a major problem: how to deal with the Viet Minh AA-guns that were seriously hampering his efforts at air resupply for the garrison. He decided that the next day he would send a large strike out to the west of the garrison’s position, tasked to capture a nest of AA batteries near the villages of Bang Ong Pet, and Ban Ban. The man he chose for the job was the most respected leader in the French garrison: Major Marcel Bigeard, affectionately known by a nick-name earned during his days in the resistance: Bruno. Behind a powerful barrage and ample air support the French attack came in. The 6th BPC (Colonial Parachute Battalion) struck Bang Ong Pet while the 8th BPC struck Ban Ban. The 8th achieved its objectives quickly, but the 6th was pinned down by stiff resistance. Three Chaffee tanks came up to reinforce the latter French assault and Viet Minh resistance soon gave way. When it was over the French were astounded at their success. Not only had they captured five 20mm AA-guns, twelve 12.7 AA MGs, and killed some 350 of the enemy, but they had done it against the elite 308th division, viewed by both armies to be the best unit the Viet Minh possessed.

Game components include:

9 maps measuring 18.5" x 12.5"
3 countersheets (1 x Viet Minh, 1 x French Infantry/Light Weapons, 1 x Vehicles)
9 AFV cards
4 scenario cards containing 7 scenarios
4 page battlefield walkaround
1 page player aid

The game depicts the action around the Eliane strongpoints of Dien Bien Phu.

Scenarios included:

The Battle for the “Five Hills” – Positions at “Eliane 1,” Dien Bien Phu, French Indochina, March 31st 1954
In French Hands - Dien Bien Phu, French Indochina, March 31st 1954
Death by Pale Moonlight – Positions at “Champs Elysees,” Dien Bien Phu, French Indochina, March 30th 1954
In the Shadow of Bazilles - Dien Bien Phu, French Indochina, May 6th 1954
The Last Day – Positions at “Elaine 4,” Dien Bien Phu, French Indochina, May 7th 1954
Mop Up - Dien Bien Phu, French Indochina, April 2nd 1954
Under Old Baldy – Champs Elysees, French Indochina, April 4th 1954

Requires ownership of the ATS Rulebook 2014 + small and large markers.

-description from publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Vietnam War, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Line of Sight, Simulation

name: Chain Mail: Tangles and Teeth – Adventure Kit
description:
She can feel your every movement in the vibrations of her web that block your way.

Find the path through and face her if you dare, but bweware the tangled web she weaves. If you get caught up, you may never escape.

Tangles and Teeth is an Adventure Kit for Chain Mail: Adventures of Earthshine.

Goal: Defeat the Spider Queen.

This expansion includes:

Quest: Tangles and Teeth
Character: Remont, Mushketeer
Map: Wildfire
Monsters: Basilisk / Snakes
Treasure: Resurrection Stone



Released in the June 2019 Board Game of the Month Club $5+ package.
categories: Adventure, Expansion for Base-game, Exploration, Fantasy, Fighting
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Modular Board, Role Playing

name: Star Trek: Customizable Card Game – Q-Continuum
description:
Expansion to the base set that is based around the mischief of Q, this set included two Side Decks, extra stacks of cards from which you could draw under certain circumstances (This became a predecessor to downloading and was the first time you could exercise any control over what you would draw); and introduced several new card-types: 'Q-related' Events, Interrupts and Dilemmas.
QC was released in 15-card expansion packs and the set included 121 cards.
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Space Exploration

name: Incredible Courage 1809, Alt-Eglofsheim
description:
This battle deals with the situation after the Battle of Eckmuhl and the French pursuit of the Austrians. General Nansouty with 3 cavalry divisions takes on a significantly smaller Austrian cavalry rearguard attempting to keep the French away from the Austrian main body, giving them time to get away. There is only cavalry and a handful of artillery batteries in this fight. It is a wild set of charges and counter-charges, with some intermittent artillery fire, spaced into a couple hours. So the battle is short and easily played in an afternoon. Counter density is low and there is some room for maneuver. Both sides have a chance to win this event. The more time the Austrians give the main body to escape the better the chance of winning.

Key Features

(4) 11" x 17" game maps of the Alt-Eglofsheim area
Approximately 600 Die Cut Unit Counters and Markers
(2) Full Color Order of Battle Charts
Numerous charts and tables
(2) Scenarios that allow play on smaller parts of the battle or the entire affair
Variable combat strengths
Reduction by Levels of Order
Cavalry units at the squadron level and artillery at the section level
Regimental level cavalry units
Highly detailed without overbearing rules
Excellent Solitaire Play


—description from the publisher

name: Star Trek: Customizable Card Game – The Trouble with Tribbles
description:
Expansion to the base set that introduced the Original Series and the "tribbles" side deck as well as introducing a format change to the cards that included listing card number and rarity in the lower right corner.

Special features include pre-constructed starter decks with premium cards in each and the return of ultra-rare cards inserted into booster packs (there would be an ultra-rare in each expansion from that point forward).

The set included 141 cards and was available in two pre-constructed 60-card starter decks (one Federation, one Klingon) and 11-card expansion packs.

This expansion featured Dr. McCoy as its ultra-rare as a tribute to DeForest Kelley, who had died the previous year.
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Space Exploration

name: Imagimarium New Year
description:
Hooray, gift edition!

Imaginarium beloved by everyone in a compact New Year's performance - this is a ready-made gift! It contains the best winter and holiday illustrations from all previous sets, but there are also new, new cards - as many as 11 pieces,
they can be mixed with any set except the Jubilee. If you add a few, you get a very different Imaginarium, It has all the components for an independent game. This is a simple association game that everyone likes - this is an excellent reason to save a couple of boxes for the winter holidays.

Rules of the game:

Each player chooses a chip and a set of voting cards in the same color as the chip.

Definition of the first move

You must determine who will walk first. You can use voting cards for this. All participants take their voting cards, shuffle and draw out any card at random. The first to start is the one who pulled out the card with the highest number. You can use any other mechanics to select the player starting first. For example, we play this right in chess. Then the game goes clockwise.

Game progress

All player chips are set to 1.
The deck with illustration cards is shuffled and each player is given 6 cards in his hands.

The player makes an association.

Each turn one of the players becomes the leader. The presenter makes an association on one of his cards, tells the association out loud to the other players and puts the hidden card upside down on the table. Each player puts out one card, the most suitable for the voiced association. Then the cards are mixed and laid out in a row.

Guessing the leader’s card.

The main task of the players is to guess which of the cards laid out on the table the presenter has guessed, and to vote for her. Each player selects one voting card with the desired number and puts it face down. The host does not vote or comment on the pictures posted on the table. You cannot vote for your own picture. When everyone made a decision and voted, the voting cards are turned over and points are scored.

Scoring

Players move their chips on the playing field by the number of steps corresponding to the number of points won.
mechanics: Communication Limits, Storytelling, Targeted Clues, Voting

name: Gold And Boom
description:
You have to dig a goldmine to collect the most gold nugget possible.
You have to memorize where the explosion are in a 4x4 matrix of cards to avoid loosing all you have collected so far.

name: Epic Monster Tea Party: Expansion
description:
This expansion to the original family-fun, tabletop game of Epic Monster Tea Party takes the 2-4 player adventure and turns it into a game for 2-6 players. (The original game is needed.)

You play as a thirsty monster plucking heroes from the labyrinth to flavor your tea. Squish the heroes to use their special abilities or drop them into your teacup for a chance to earn victory points after the end up in your stomach.

The addition of Miss Hiss the Gorgon and Merv Griffin the, well... Griffin, allows 2 extra players to join the game. Don't worry, there will be plenty of heroes to heartily flavor everyone's tea because 22 more of them have wandered into the labyrinth!

—description from the publisher

name: Monopoly: Cats vs Dogs
description: Two teams of players try to capture pet show titles in this variation on Monopoly. When landing on previously claimed spaces, players can opt to pay tribute to the holder or add their own token as they vie for control.

name: Detective Conan: Suspect Criminal
description:
Detective Conan: Suspect Criminal เกมสัญญาณปริศนา

It is a real-time party game that uses signaling, bluffing, and deduction.

In a mystery old castle, it was suppose to be a vacation but a murder happen.

The objective of the police is to find the killer before the killer eliminates all of the civilians.

The killer's intention is to eliminate innocent civilians by means of a secret signal. The killer has less than five minutes to secretly signal their murder target without revealing themselves to the police. If the killer's murder attempt is successful, they will need to wait for at least 10 seconds before making another attempt. In the meantime, the killer is also trying to confuse the police into capturing the wrong player.

Civilian roles make the game more complex and interesting. The Journalist, for example, is an innocent civilian with the ability to expose other player's characters.

The game includes 30 characters with 10 unique roles. Each roles has a different agenda. Various characters can help the police or the killer or even themselves to win the game.

This game is easy to play, and can be played anywhere--in a small circle of friends or with family or as a team-building exercise.

—description from the designer
categories: Bluffing, Deduction, Murder/Mystery, Party Game, Real-time
mechanics: Acting, Real-Time, Role Playing, Roles with Asymmetric Information
publishers: BGA Plus, Kidz & Kitz, Wise Box

name: Jinrou (SUPER DX)
description:
A new and expanded version of the classic party game Werewolf, with 24 total roles and gorgeous, full-color art. Includes several new roles and optional rules not present in the publisher's previous werewolf game, such as 3-faction play.

(from the back of the box): Who are the wolves pretending to be human!? The largest pack in the Werewolf series, which introduces a new third team—neither werewolf nor citizen—into the fray!

A battle between the "Wolf Team"—that hides its true nature and slips into human society—the "Citizen Team"—which must scrutinize others' behavior and identify the wolves, and the mysterious "Third Party"—which fights in secret to survive until the very end. Who is your ally, who is your enemy, and who will survive? This is the ultimate "talk-battle" game, where you can enjoy the thrill of psychological bargaining, and the pleasure of seeing through the acts of others.
mechanics: Alliances, Betting and Bluffing, Deduction, Hidden Roles, Negotiation, Player Elimination, Role Playing, Team-Based Game, Traitor Game, Variable Player Powers, Voting

name: Vanguard of War: Harbinger
description:
Brings The Harbinger, a hero from Load, to Vanguard of War.

Contains
1 boss
5 abominations
6 stat cards
5 spawn cards
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Triumph of the Temple
description:
The artifact matching, jewel-winning quest!

“You’ve discovered an Egyptian pyramid filled with temple jewels and ancient artifacts that need repair. It’s up to you to fix them in order to be rewarded with the jewels of the temple. Your Quest Cards will tell you which artifacts you can fix on your turn. The player who collects the most jewels will be the one to triumph over the temple.”
—description from the rulebook

In this game, you have a hand of 3 tiles. you then draw a Quest Card from the deck and it will tell you which artifacts that are listed on the tiles will score you points that turn. Match up as many symbols on the cards as you can and you will get a jewel for each correct match.
—user summary
mechanics: Pattern Building, Square Grid, Tile Placement

name: Song Saga
description: Song Saga challenges players to tell song- and music-related stories.

name: Taboo Code: Red
description:
In Taboo Code: Red (タブーコード・レッド), each player has a card placed in front of them that can be seen by all the other players. (Each card has two words or phrases on it on opposite ends of the card, and whichever end is up is what's important.) The word or phrase in front of you is your taboo code.

Everyone then starts talking, with you trying to lure the other players into saying what is taboo for them. If they say their taboo code, then they're out of the round.

name: Snits!
description:
Snits! is a compilation of Tom Wham's two Snits games: Snit Smashing and Snit's Revenge. Both games have been developed by Steve Jackson and so have some changes from earlier versions:


Snit Smashing has extensive changes, including a different board size, fixed movement rates for Snits, no written Snit orders, six rounds to a set (game phase) instead of nine, etc.



Snit's Revenge has an altered Bolotomus turn order, a change to how Snorgs (organs) are replaced, standard Snit abilities instead of optional (and they are different), and a few other changes.
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid

name: Funkytown
description:
Move and groove your way into Funkytown.

Inspired on the one hit wonder song Funkytown by Lipps Inc..


Funkytown is an action selection game of dancing down the road to Funkytown. Players use a deck of cards to simulate their moves and guide their tokens on the board to the section of Funkytown that they have to reach. First player to reach their location wins and gets their groove on.


Funkytown is the postcard game from Button Shy's November 2017 edition of the Board Game of the Month club.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: 200 Years Army Lists
description:
Army Lists for Two Hundred Years 5mm Wargames Rules 1700-1900. Including lists for the Marlburian Period, Great North War, 18th Century, Seven Years War, American War of Independence, Revolutionary Wars, Napoleonic Wars, India 1840-1850, Mexico, Crimean War, Mid 19th Century, American Civil War, Mexican War, Late 19th Century and British Colonial Wars.

These army lists are unusual in that they contain between 80 and 100 armies from the period 1700 – 1900. Virtually every army list is taken from a specific battle or campaign and is given at least a paragraph of background information – so, unlike other books of army lists, it is much more a compilation of historical research adapted to a specific set of rules. The contents page lists:

Marlburian period (5 Armies)
Great Northern War (2 Armies)
Seven Years War (6 Armies)
American War of Independence (3 Armies)
French Revolutionary Wars (4 Armies)
Napoleonic Wars (26 Armies)
Indian Campaign 1840-1850 (2 Armies)
Mexican American Wars (2 Armies)
Crimean (3 Armies)
Mid-19th Century (3 Armies including Garibaldi – Italian War of Independence)
ACW and Mexican Wars (9 Armies)
Late 19th Century (7 Armies including USA and Indian Wars)
British Colonial 1879-1890 (6 Armies including Zulu, Afghan & Mahdist)

The last two pages, 65 and 66, contain rule amendments and corrections.
categories: Age of Reason, American Civil War, American Indian Wars, American Revolutionary War, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Post-Napoleonic, Wargame

name: Миксология
description:
This game is for 2-5 people and can be played by the whole family and company friends. The main thing before the game is delicious to eat, as it causes appetite.
Your goal is to get the most points, and for that you will need to collect from spices aromatic seasonings - mixes, prepare delicious dishes, and also discover countries where these spices grow.

name: Universal Rule: Duplicity
description:
Chip Beauvais has designed a full standalone expansion for Universal Rule and we're sending it out in 3 parts. This first set, which we're calling Duplicity is all about doubling abilities. Want to attack twice? Or colonize twice? These cards will allow you to bend the rules in that new way.

—description from the publisher


This expansion is included in the base game set Universal Rule: Second Wave.


A 6-card expansion to the Universal Rule family of games. This expansion adds 6 new planets to explore that adds additional rules and ways to score.

The main theme of this expansion is cards that double things.



Escalating Edge


Planets

Antedock
Fixtau
Mannisoni
Piscius VI
Wachu
Zeffe



Released in the July 2017 Board Game of the Month Club $10+ package.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Print & Play, Science Fiction, Space Exploration

name: Universal Rule: Attack! Attack!
description:
This expansion is included in the base game set Universal Rule: Second Wave.


A 6-card expansion to the Universal Rule family of games. This expansion adds 5 new planets to explore and the Escalating Edge card that adds additional rules and ways to score.

The main theme of this expansion is cards that emphasize attack.



Escalating Edge


Planets:

Pospars
Ascore
Ocuchines
Stegater
Panthia



Released in the November 2017 Board Game of the Month Club $10+ package.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Print & Play, Science Fiction, Space Exploration

name: Universal Rule: Magnitude
description:
This expansion is included in the base game set Universal Rule: Second Wave.


A 6-card expansion to the Universal Rule family of games. This expansion adds 6 new planets to explore that adds additional rules and ways to score.

The main theme of this expansion is cards that make things bigger.


Planets:

Sietynas
Innollica
Kothar
Galvacil
Pharamme
Outis



Released in the September 2017 Board Game of the Month Club $10+ package.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Print & Play, Science Fiction, Space Exploration

name: Beach Life
description:
While building a giant sandcastle, you notice that you are sharing the beach with a variety of sea-dwellers. You discard your bucket and space to give the creatures a helping hand. Get points for helping each animal, most points wins.

Beach Life is a 'roll and write' game. One player rolls the dice and each player decides how they will use the dice rolls on their own board. One dice determines which mini game you are working on, another determines the number you'll use within that game. The number on the third dice can be used five times in the game as a bonus action.

The game finishes when one player has taken three 'no throws'.

Beach Life is a 'Placemat' game - a game contained entirely within an A3 placemat (including the rules). Just add three standard D6 dice.

On the reverse side of each placemat is a second game - Castaway.

Both games have a desert island theme.

—description from the designer

name: 52 Dragons
description:
52 Dragons is a fantasy card game where players draw from the same deck to power a unique Battle Dragon based on the four elements of fire, air, water, or earth.

The game play is fairly simple. Each player controls a Battle Dragon starting with 52 Health Points. They attack an opposing Battle Dragon by rolling dice to inflict damage. Cards are drawn and played to grant abilities to the dragons, regain Health Points, increase the damage of the roll, or summon supporting dragons to join the attack.

A player is eliminated when their Health Points reach 0, and the game ends when only one player remains.

52 Dragons is designed for 2-4 players, ages 12 and up. A game can be a quick as a few minutes or as long as a half-hour.

This Basic Set contains 52 distinct playing cards, 2 reversible Battle Dragon cards, and the instruction manual.
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Dice Rolling, Open Drafting

name: Little Living Dungeon
description:
They say write the book you want to read, well I wanted a dice based dungeon delving game where you got to use Mana to grow your dungeon and it was in a cute mint tin, but there was none. So I made it!! I have been a big fan of Dungeon Core fiction for ages and thought that being able to physically build your own adventurer trap would be cool.

Little Living Dungeon is a mint tin game so it is small and portable, you start with your core room, and a small amount of Mana to grow your dungeon by adding extra rooms, at the end each day a adventurer will enter your dungeon to try and get to the core, and you will hopefully fight them off, as you grow your dungeon the adventurers get stronger and more of them. All combat is dice roll based.

—description from the designer

name: CARD TRIP: Brussels
description:
CARD Trip is a unique game allowing you to discover a city by making a 3-day trip with playing cards.
With its simple game system: Draw / Place / Discard, start a game alone or with your loved ones in 5 minutes to make the best stay!

The goal of CARD Trip is to make the best stay by playing and combining cards from Collections, Activities, Relaxations and Discoveries. These categories allow you to score points in a variety of ways and to interact with other players.

The stay lasts 3 days and each day is divided into 4 phases: morning, noon, afternoon and evening. At each phase of the day and in turn, the players draw a card, place one face down and discard another. Each player's laid cards form a line representing their stay.
At the end of the game, the total score of the players is calculated by counting the points of the cards in each category. To win: accumulate different Collection cards, play the same types of Activities as the others, share meals or rest with Relaxations and be the only one to make unique Discoveries.

—description from the designer

name: Botany the Print and Play
description:
Botany is a botanical themed tabletop game where players take on the role of a botanist collecting plant samples in their botanical journal. This tableau-building card game plays with 2-5 players in about 45 minutes.

Each player will take turns playing cards into their tableau. The cards in their tableau will allow them to collect Plant Tokens which can be traded in for victory points. As Plant Tokens are traded in, their value goes down. At the end of the game, the player with the most victory points wins!

-description from designer

name: Krynea Battlefield: Expansiones 1 y 2
description:
Champions of Light and Lords of Darkness are the first two factions to have their own expansion. 25 cards per faction, 50 total, with 10 action cards, 14 troop cards (including 1 new Champion and 1 Magic Item) and 1 new exclusive ability for each faction.

The two expansions are presented together in a single cardboard box, in the most classic style of traditional poker cards. Sizes 63x88mm, finished in 300gr with casino varnish, packed in a 50 card case.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy

name: Napoleon in Italy (2nd edition)
description:
Napoleon in Italy 2nd ed. is an operational level game of strategy based on the 1796 Italian Campaign between French and Austrian troops.

This edition contains revised rules and new components.

Division level, turns represent three days, with the first game turn being November 9-11, 1796.

Includes: 12 page rules (standard and optional), Roster Sheets, small game map, set of 16 counters, Designer's Notes.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Point to Point Movement, Simulation

name: Florida Man Card Game
description:
Florida Man is a party card game where players try to fill in the blanks on actual criminal cases in Florida. One player is the judge and plays a real headline from a Florida cases with some details left blank. The other players then submit their best guess to fill in the blank. The judge then decides the best guess and awards the card to that player. The person awarded the most headline cards at the end of the game is the winner.

Includes:
100 Headline Cards
306 Action Cards
2 Decoder Cards
1 Headline Card Stand
1 Instruction Sheet

name: RuneSword: Endril – Elfin Archer with Epee
description:
A thematic series in the Lost Worlds series (these books are even compatible with the others). Players each take a character represented with a game book and a stat sheet. By giving the book to the opposite player, the pages give a first person view to the combatants. As various moves direct the players to turn to this page or that, combat damage, restrictions, and other special events are relayed to the players via the pages of the book.

Part of the Lost Worlds series of books.

name: Lost Worlds: "Arafael" the Angel
description:
Lost Worlds is the most popular entry in Alfred Leonardi's line of book games, which also includes Ace of Aces. Each player has a character card and a booklet (and sometimes special Tactics, Luck, or Spell cards) for one of about fifty (and growing) medieval-fantasy characters. Characters can range from barbarian warriors to animated skeletons to elven archers to unicorns — even two different dragons. Booklets are traded and, as each player selects a move, a reference grid in the books determine the results (wounds, off-balance maneuvers, and so on). Combat continues until one fighter or the other expires.

An interesting feature of the Lost Worlds system is that, under some versions of the rules, characters may improve their abilities as they gain experience. In theory, you are supposed to keep track of your progress with each character, and if one is utterly killed, it will have to start over without its improved skills.

Part of the Lost Worlds series of books.
mechanics: Rock-Paper-Scissors, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers

name: JINGI
description:
In the two-player competitive card game JINGI, Chaos battles against Law to claim the sacred treasure named in the game's title in order to rebuild the world.

In the game, players place gods (cards) on a 3x3 field to try to complete a row. A battle of the gods is initiated when three cards are placed in a row. The player who initiated that battle moves the JINGI token one space towards their side, and the player who wins that battle also moves the JINGI token in the same way. If the JINGI token is closer to your side at the end of the game, you win. Alternatively, play three of your gods in a single row to win immediately.

name: Titania Ascending
description:
STORY:
Titania, Queen of the Fae, has grown tired of humanity’s disdain for nature’s splendor. She plans to liberate Gaia, and has summoned you, her High Council of Sorcerers to manifest her will.

Work together to consult the heavens and read runes. Mobilize Titania’s loyal Fae and port them to Gaia, where they will recover her crown from the six hallowed citadels. Will you divine the path to victory? Gather your golems! Summon your sirens! The Earth trembles before... Titania Ascending.

GAME OVERVIEW:
Titania Ascending is a cooperative “flip and write” (and write) game for two to six players in which you and your friends become Titania’s trusted High Council, coordinating the liberation of Gaia. In phase 1, you will populate your map with the units you want to send to Gaia; in phase 2, you will use your completed map to support the invasion.

FILL IN YOUR MAP:
In phase 1, Divination, you arrange Fae and Dragons, recruit aides (special assistants), and select the hallowed units who will seize the 6 hallowed citadels and secure the Shards of Gaia for Titania’s crown. Take turns choosing which unit everyone will draw on their maps (map/player board), coordinating with other players to divine hallowed units, and recruit aides to earn rule-bending abilities. The phase succeeds when all six hallowed units have been divined. You fail if everyone passes before you complete this goal.

USE YOUR MAP:
In phase 2, Ascension, you open portals to Gaia (Earth) and send Titania’s units into the field, using your hallowed units to seize the hallowed citadels. Take turns selecting missions to launch and shading in areas on your map that meet the mission requirements; meanwhile, the other players fill in similar areas on their maps. After you launch each mission, you can also send your hallowed units to capture the hallowed citadels. If you capture all six citadels, you restore Titania’s crown, she ascends the throne of Gaia, and you win.

WINNING AND LOSING:
You win together by divining six hallowed units during the Divination phase, then by capturing the six hallowed citadels in the Ascension, thus taking control of Gaia and saving the humans from themselves.

The whole team loses together in two ways:
In phase one, Divination, you lose if all players pass before the six hallowed units have been divined.
In phase two, Ascension, you lose if all players pass before claiming all six Shards of Gaia.

-description from publisher
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Grid Coverage, Open Drafting, Paper-and-Pencil, Solo / Solitaire Game
publishers: Rattlebox Games, XYZ Game Labs, Inc

name: Zombies!!!: I Don't Feel So Good! Promo Card
description: All players discards down to one health.

name: Dirt Dog
description:
Use the unique skill of your pup to overcome obstacles and catch prized quarries in the underground world of Dirt Dog. Create challenges for your opponent to find out whose dog has the most moxie in the end!

Loosely based on the real world dog sport of Earth Dog, the game Dirt Dog has players leading their dog through underground burrows to try and track down quarry. Badgers, foxes, rabbits, and others are all things for your dog to chase.

Play begins with players drafting obedience cards, which are used to help their dogs overcome obstacles within the burrows. One player then constructs a burrow for the other player to run. While running the burrow, both players may use obedience cards to make the challenges easier or more difficult for the dogs. Failing to meet a challenge saps some of the dogs moxie, which is needed to make it through the burrow and defeat the quarry at the end. The dog with the most moxie at the end of the round wins that round. Best of 3 rounds wins the game.

Dirt Dog is playable as either a head vs head game or team vs team. Team games have 2 players per team, called a brace. Players in a brace help each other successfully run through burrows to try and make sure they make it to the end with more moxie than their opponents.

—description from the designer

name: Gamut
description:
Gamut is a card game about colors.

The goal is to connect the primary colors between them, a player wins when they have no more cards in their hand.

As the game progresses, a beautiful pattern grows on the table.

name: スーパーマリオ バランスゲーム キノコがいっぱい (Super Mario Balance Game: A Lot of Mushrooms)
description: In this dexterity game, you balance little plastic mushrooms on top of a pipe from super mario bros.

name: 13 Monsters: Armed to the Teeth
description:
13 Monsters: Armed to the Teeth is an expansion pack for 13 Monsters that adds weapons, armor, loot piles, new metal-type monsters, extra battle/loot mechanics and the oddest smithy anyone has ever met; Trall.

The added game elements fit neatly in the already-established player rounds from the base game and opens up many new opportunities during each players turn. Throw the new action granting dice to score loot from the armory. Equip your monsters with weapons and Armour, each with their own special abilities that affect the card-collection phase, battles or even your opponents monsters.

—description from the designer
categories: Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game, Memory
mechanics: Chaining, Deck Construction, Matching, Memory, Negotiation, Once-Per-Game Abilities, Passed Action Token, Tile Placement, Trading, Variable Phase Order, Variable Player Powers
publishers: Playing With Strangers B.V., Twisted Stranger B.V.

name: Steamrolled
description:
A game for all types of gamers. Roll custom dice and move your Steampunk inspired wooden pawn onto a betting track. Move up and including your dice roll to maneuver your pawn into a pot winning position or block your opponents from taking the pot.

2 solitaire versions, 4 different variations to play.

For 1-8 players with the ability to add as many players as you want with your own tokens. Each round takes 5-10 minutes and players play as many rounds as they like, or as determined by a dice roll.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Dice Rolling, Different Dice Movement, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Play the Naval Battle of Tsushima 1905
description:
Play the Naval Battle of Tsushima 1905 is volume 9 of the series "Paper Battles & Dioramas".
The booklet contains a large number of color illustrations of ships from the time of the sea battle of Tsushima in 1905, representing all the different types of ships in the Russian and Japanese fleets.
The Battle of Tsushima on May 27 and 28, 1905, was the final and decisive battle of the Russo-Japanese War (1904-1905).

The ships shown in the work can be photocopied and then cut out in order to put together an army for a tabletop strategy game or for display.

name: Santa Kids
description:
The long awaited Christmas. Santa's kids are up for it again this year!
Take the presents on a sled at the factory and deliver them to cities around the world.
Many happenings are waiting for you on the way.
Who will collect the most bells, a sign of gratitude, before the morning arrives?

To Win:
Whoever collects the most bells at the end of the night wins.

How to play:
The rules of Santa Kids are very simple.
There are only four actions to choose from.
They are easy to understand: Grab a present, Move, Distribute a present, and Get a reindeer or sled.
Play as many of these actions as you have reindeer, and your turn is up.
Give out presents of the same color as the socks in each city, and collect as many bells as you can!
Fun events occur while you're playing! It's snowing and a nice wind. All sorts of happenings, like being called by Papa Santa and secret loopholes, make the game so much more exciting!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Action Points, Events, Pick-up and Deliver
publishers: Studium Mundi (スタジオムンディ)

name: Monopoly: FC De Kampioenen
description:
FC De Kampioenen: the most fun and popular football team in Flanders now also has its own MONOPOLY edition.

Discover the iconic locations from the series. Buy Fernand's dovecote or Carmen's newsagents shop. And who knows, you might become the new owner of the soccer field of De Kampioenen.

Another window broken? "Zal ‘t gaan, ja??" That's a 100M fine.
Do you win the dog show with Nero? Tournée général! You pay each other player 50M.
categories: Economic, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Negotiation
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: AXIO: Duel Hexagonal
description:
New duel variant for 2 players, with an additional duel board and 6 duel tokens.

How to play:

Setup: Instead of using individual score boards, place the duel board between the two players. Use only one set of counters, placing one counter of each colour on the dividing line in the middle of each track on the duel board.

Gameplay: Play as usual. When you score, advance the respective colour counters on the duel board in your direction. You cannot advance the counters beyond the final space (value 9) on your side of the duel board. For each counter that reaches the final space, call out “Axio” and place the corresponding duel token face up in front of you. Then you get an instant bonus play of one tile as usual.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Expansion for Base-game, Print & Play
mechanics: Hand Management, Highest-Lowest Scoring, Pattern Building, Tile Placement

name: ELEKTRICO
description: A roll & write game in which our task is to power a bizarre machine constructed by a mad scientist. In each of the 8 rounds of the game, a set of dice are used to strengthen selected connections. At the end of each round, players choose how the scoring will work, the choice is very important because the same connections will be run several times during the game. The game provides intense intellectual gameplay and a lot of combinations.

name: Implo
description:
IntroductionImplo is a finite territory game for two players: Black and White. It is played on the intersections (points) of an initially empty square board. The recommended board sizes are between 6x6 and 10x10. Each player must have access to a sufficient number of stones and markers of their own color.



DefinitionsIn these rules, "adjacent" always means "orthogonally adjacent".

A group is a piece along with all other pieces one could reach from it through a series of steps between identical adjacent pieces. Thus, all pieces in a group are the same type (stone or marker) and color (black or white).

The size of a group is the number of pieces in it.

Likewise, a territory is an empty point along with all other points one could reach from it through a series of steps between adjacent empty points.

A patch is a territory including at most four points.

The owner of a patch is the player with the biggest group of stones adjacent to it. If there is no such group or the biggest such groups of both colors are the same size, the owner of the patch is the opponent of the player who placed the last stone on the board.

To resolve a patch is to place a marker of its owner's color on each of its points and to remove the biggest group of stones which is adjacent to the patch and owned by the same player as the patch. If several such groups are tied for biggest, the player who is resolving the patch removes, among those, one of their choosing. If there are no groups of stones adjacent to the patch, no group is removed. Note the player resolving the patch need not be the owner of the patch.



PlayBlack plays first, then turns alternate. On your turn, perform these actions in order:

1. Place a stone of your color on an empty point of the board.

2. Resolve any single patch on the board.

3. Repeat the previous step until no patches remain. Note the order of resolving matters, and resolving a patch may create new patches.

If, at the end of a player's turn, there are no empty points on the board, the game ends. The winner is the player with more groups of markers of the largest size of which there is an unequal number of black and white groups of markers. If there is a tie, whoever has more stones on the board wins. If this is also tied (only possible on even-sized boards), whoever made the last move loses.



Pie ruleThe pie rule is used in order to make the game fair. This means White will have the option, on their first turn only, to swap sides with their opponent instead of making a regular move.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Chaining, Enclosure, Pattern Recognition, Square Grid, Tile Placement

name: Qube: På spåret
description:
Trivia game based on the popular swedish quiz show "På spåret". Two teams takes three turns each, guessing a city destinations and answering questions about them.

On a turn the active team first tries guess the destination by listening to progressively easier clues. For each clue needed, the points value for the correct answer drops, but a wrong answer scores 0 points. Then the active team is asked four questions related to the destination, worth a point for each correct answer.
The team with the most points at the wins.

name: Minerały: Promo 1 – Pomost (Wollastonit)
description: Additional tile with special "teleport" ablity.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Modular Board, Pattern Building, Set Collection, Tile Placement

name: Nebuchadnezzar
description:
Rules

Nebuchadnezzar is a game of annihilation for two players. Not only are draws impossible in Nebuchadnezzar, almost any game of Nebuchadnezzar played to its conclusion will end with a board completely filled with a single color of disc.

Materials: A square board of any size (nothing bigger than 15x15 is recommended due to the amount of recycling and potential number of moves along with the amount of mechanical flipping involved) and an unlimited supply of discs with each player's color on either side. Go stones can also be used if you're willing to replace them instead of flip discs. (note: If you have an Othello set, 8x8 is a fine size to get started with)

Objective: wipe your opponent completely off the board!

Gameplay: Starting with black, on his turn a player may place a disc with his color facing up as long as it isn't orthogonally adjacent to exactly 1 enemy disc and 3 empty points. He may alternatively capture enemy discs according to the following convention. He cannot place and capture on the same turn.

A player may flip a rectangle of discs consisting purely of enemy discs, if the following qualifications are met


The rectangle is entirely bounded by single-colored walls (of discs) on all 4 of its sides
The player owns the majority of the perimeter created by these walls
The rectangle is not part of a bigger rectangle meeting these criteria.


Edge rule: If one or more of the walls bounding a rectangle are board edges these will take on the color of the parallel walls opposite to them. If a rectangle is bounded by two opposite board edges then these are considered to be neutral walls.

Forced passing: You automatically pass your turn if no legal move is available for you on your turn. Otherwise passing is not permitted

Pie: After the first move, the second player may choose to switch colors instead of playing a disc of his color for his first move.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Enclosure, I Cut, You Choose, Lose a Turn, Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Square Grid

name: Puppy Power
description:
Puppy Power is a free print&play 52-card puzzle game for 1 (solo) or 2 players (head to head)

The puppy's stuff is all over the place and you have to order all of it exactly right using a mancala style system.

Both players get a set of 5 Puppy Stuff cards which they put face-up in this pattern : 2 cards above the Puppy card, 1 to the right, 1 at the bottom and 1 to the left.

Both players draw an Order card.
